This type of membership is virtually unique among higher education associations, but necessary since all sectors of campus must work collaboratively and learn from each other in advancing sustainability. Join the AASHE community today!

If individual faculty members, students, staff or administrators were to join, it would be harder to get the commitment of the entire institution and to work across sectors, which is necessary for campus sustainability work.

In addition to college and university memberships, AASHE offers an array of business memberships, which we refer to as the Business Alliance program. Dues for participation in the Business Alliance vary based on the size of the company and level of benefits. More information about the Business Alliance program is available online.

Other

Can a vendor/supplier of sustainability products apply for STARS Certification for Universities to apply towards their STARS Rating?
STARS is a self-assessment for colleges and universities. Participating schools receive a rating. It is not a certification system and STARS does not endorse products. However, products with certain attributes or products that deliver a specific outcome may contribute to campuses earning credits in STARS. I encourage you to check out the STARS Credit Checklist for an overview of the credits and review the details included in the STARS Technical Manual for more specific information including credit criteria.

Our university will register for STARS this year and plans to hire a third party consultant to help with the effort. Do you have any advice for working with these types of consultants? How does one go about identifying local qualified consultants who can assist universities in conducting a STARs assessment?
Since STARS has just launched, we don’t yet have a sense of the experiences of those campuses that have worked with consultants on their data collection process. We welcome participating schools to post ideas and feedback to AASHE's Campus Sustainability Discussion Forums, a great resource for STARS Participants. In time, AASHE will offer suggestions and perhaps even guidelines for how campuses can best accomplish their STARS assessment internally or through a third party consultant. At this point, we would encourage campuses to be sure that the consultant is familiar with the STARS Technical Manual and the credit requirements. It would also be good to make sure a consultant is familiar with the process of using the STARS Reporting Tool. There will be a webinar in February that will provide an online demonstration of how the Reporting Tool works.

Will there be more training available for faculty to infuse sustainability into the curriculum (in addition to AASHE's workshops)?
In addition to the Sustainability Across the Curriculum Leadership Workshops, AASHE’s annual conference includes sessions and workshops on sustainability curriculum. AASHE 2010, our next conference, will take place in Denver, Colorado, from October 10 to 12. Archives from the 2008 conference are available online.

Additional training opportunities will be announced in the AASHE Bulletin, our free, weekly newsletter.

Knowing the urgency to address climate change immediately; knowing the extent of change required in reducing the energy intensity of our energy use, food production and diet, building operations, transportation and waste generation patterns and habits; is it not necessary for Higher Ed to shift to draconian measures such as banning cars on campus, reducing meat offerings for dining services, going to a paperless communications system, etc. immediately? Is it reasonable to think we can take 20 years of collegial dialogue and discussion to move this agenda?
AASHE certainly recognizes the importance and immediacy of the challenges we are facing today. We think STARS will be a powerful tool in addressing sustainability challenges, especially since STARS recognizes outcomes and focuses on performance. STARS provides guidelines for embracing sustainability but also allows flexibility for campuses to decide the best approach. To learn more about these approaches or get other perspectives, we encourage you to start a conversation using AASHE’s Campus Sustainability Discussion Forums.

Are there templates available for a letter to send to departments and administrators about STARS?
We don't have template letters yet, but this is a great suggestion and we'll work on developing them. 

Does STARS have a Life Cycle Analysis tool for materials used on Campuses?
STARS does not have a lifecycle analysis tool for materials used on campus. I suspect many institutions would benefit from such an instrument, but it's beyond the scope of the program at this time. You may wish to post this question to AASHE's Campus Sustainability Discussion Forums to see if others have resources to recommend.

Chris O’Brien mentioned incorporating sustainability initiatives into the American University campus grounds department. Could you give us a brief overview of what is being done?
From Chris O’Brien: We are about to become a pilot campus for Sustainable Sites. This is sustainable grounds-keeping program builds on LEED but goes much deeper in the area of grounds. They are still seeking pilot campuses, so I encourage you to considering applying.

As the recently appointed Director of Sustainability at American University, how have you (the position) been received by the campus community?
From Chris O’Brien: My role at AU has been received with open arms by everyone I encounter on campus. I have approached people all across the campus community to introduce them to STARS and request their participation in the credits relevant to their function. In most cases, I have found that people are doing sustainability activities already which weren’t centrally planned or organized. In a number of cases, when I have asked people to do specific sustainability activities, they have responded with: “Oh! That’s great. I have suggested this in the past, so I’m glad you’re asking me to do it!”

In short, there has been latent sustainability energy lying just under the surface all over our campus. Tasking an office and an individual with planning, implementing and tracking sustainability has made all the difference in turning that latent energy into real activities. People feel that their sustainability efforts are now part of a bigger picture. Because they see how their efforts are contributing to a shared goal, they can also share in the success once we achieve our STARS rating.

fields.title: Free Tier
fields.content:
In 2012, AASHE launched two initiatives to facilitate higher education sustainability reporting and data sharing:

  • The Campus Sustainability Data Collector (CSDC) , a free tool for U.S. institutions to share data with organizations such as Sierra Magazine and The Princeton Review
  • The STARS International Pilot, an opportunity for colleges and universities located outside the U.S. and Canada to participate in STARS at no cost to share feedback and make suggestions for improvements to the system.

In response to participant feedback and to make STARS accessible to all higher education institutions, AASHE is fully integrating the CSDC and international participation into STARS to coincide with the launch of STARS 2.0.


What Does it Look Like?

Very little will change. There will be a unified STARS Reporting Tool with two levels of access;  institutions will be able to decide at which level they want to participate:

Level of Access

STARS Subscription (paid) 

Basic Access  (free)

Features/Benefits


 

Continuous access to the STARS Reporting Tool

Multiple user accounts

Ability to share data with third parties

Submitted data posted on STARS website

Access to Resources 

Full access to Data Displays

Public recognition as a STARS subscriber

Automated scoring

Benchmarking opportunities

Data exports

API access

Single-click export of STARS Reports to Snapshots

Continuous access to the STARS Reporting Tool

Multiple user accounts

Ability to share data with third parties

Submitted data posted on STARS website

Access to Resources (AASHE members)


 
 

Levels of Recognition Available

A participant that earns the points to do so may receive a STARS Bronze, Silver, Gold or Platinum rating. Submitting for a rating will make data and scores public.

All participants have the option to submit data to AASHE as STARS Reporters, regardless of access level. Doing so will make data public, but not scores.


Registration and Participation

My institution is already participating in STARS

Institutions that have registered for STARS will not need to re-register. An institution with a STARS subscription will retain all the benefits associated with the subscription, including the ability to pursue a STARS rating. An institution with an expired subscription will retain basic access to the Reporting Tool and also have the option to submit their data as a STARS Reporter.

My institution is already using the Campus Sustainability Data Collector

Institutions that have registered for the CSDC will not need to re-register for STARS. All CSDC Survey Respondents will automatically be registered as STARS Participants under the basic access option and will have the option to share their data publicly as STARS Reporters. Participants may purchase a STARS subscription from within the Reporting Tool at any time.

My institution is an International Pilot Participant

Institutions that have registered for the STARS International Pilot will not need to re-register for STARS. All pilot participants will automatically be registered as STARS Participants under the basic access option and will have the option to share their data publicly as STARS Reporters. Participants may purchase a STARS subscription from within the Reporting Tool at any time.

My institution has not registered

Institutions that have never registered for STARS, the CSDC, or the International Pilot can either register for STARS under the basic access option or purchase a STARS subscription. A STARS subscription may also be purchased at any time from within the STARS Reporting Tool.

 

Get started with registration.

fields.title: Historic Documents
fields.content:
Before launching the current version of STARS, AASHE released several earlier drafts for public comment. Key documents from throughout the STARS development process are posted below.

STARS 1.x

AASHE launched the STARS 1.0 Early Release in September 2009 that included all of the credits but limited supporting information as a sneak peek to those interested in participating. AASHE made minor administrative updates after releasing this document that were incorporated in STARS 1.0 that launched in January 2010.

  • STARS 1.0 Early Release Technical Manual (pdf)
  • The STARS Technical Manual Record of Changes (pdf) details the minor differences between the Early Release edition and the January 2010 updated edition.

AASHE incorporated additional support information in the Technical Manual after the early release and launched the completed STARS 1.0 Technical Manual, website, and Reporting Tool in January 2010. AASHE issued an Administrative Update to this version in June 2010 and November 2011.

  • STARS 1.0 Technical Manual (January 2010 edition) (pdf)
  • Record of Changes (pdf) details the changes between the January 2010 and June 2010 edition
  • STARS 1.0 Technical Manual (June 2010 edition) (pdf)
  • Record of Changes (pdf) details the changes between the June 2010 and November 2010 edition.
  • STARS 1.0 Credit Checklist (pdf or xls)

AASHE launched STARS 1.1 Administrative Update One in February 2011. This Administrative Update contains basic system maintenance changes to STARS 1.1, such as additional language to clarify credits and correction of typographical errors.

  • STARS 1.1 Administrative Update One Technical Manual (pdf)
  • Record of changes (pdf) details the changes between STARS 1.0 Administrative Update Two and STARS 1.1 Administrative Update One.
  • STARS 1.1 Credit Checklist (pdf or xls)

AASHE released STARS 1.2 in February 2012.  Like the changes from STARS 1.0 to STARS 1.1, this version of STARS includes minor updates to the system.

  • STARS 1.2 Technical Manual (pdf)
  • Record of changes (pdf) details the changes between STARS 1.1 Administrative Update One and STARS 1.2

Learn how credits were organized and weighed in each of the STARS 1.x versions of the Technical Manual.

STARS International Pilot Project

The STARS International Pilot project took place from October 2011 and December 2013.  All institutions of higher education outside of the US and Canada were welcome to register for the current STARS system, completed a STARS Report as a STARS Reporter, and give feedback on how STARS could be shaped to better fit international needs. Learn more about the STARS International Pilot (pdf).

STARS Pilot Project

The STARS pilot project took place from February 2008 to January 2009 and involved 66 institutions in the US and Canada. Learn additional details about the STARS Pilot Project including the overall approach, participating institutions, and notes from conference calls.  

  • STARS Guide to Pilot Phase One (pdf)
  • STARS Guide to Pilot Phase Two (pdf)
  • Pilot Project Results (pdf) 

STARS 0.x

AASHE released STARS 0.5 in April 2008.

  • STARS 0.5 (pdf)
  • Feedback on STARS 0.5 (pdf) 

AASHE released STARS 0.4 in September 2007.

  • STARS 0.4 (pdf)
  • Comments on STARS 0.4 (pdf)
  • Responses to STARS 0.4 Survey (pdf)
  • Notes from conference calls about STARS 0.4

Predecessors of STARS

  • Campus Sustainability Rating System (CSRS) 0.1 (pdf) - released January 2007
  • Original Campus Sustainability Rating System Proposal (pdf) - released January 2007
  • Sustainability in Higher Education Assessment Framework (SHEAF) - a 2006 project that grew to become STARS

Summary Notes from Conference Workshops

  • Smart and Sustainable Campuses Conference (pdf) - April 2007
  • Rocky Mountain Sustainability Summit (pdf) - Feb. 2007

Other Historic Documents

  • STARS Governance Structure (pdf) - Jan. 2010
  • HEASC Call for a Campus Sustainability Rating System (pdf) - Aug. 2006
  • Listen to the STARS podcast (18 minutes) -- Feb. 2008

fields.title: History
fields.content:
[PREFER TO REPLACE WITH A TIMELINE VISUAL]

In August 2006, the Higher Education Associations Sustainability Consortium (HEASC), an informal network of higher education associations with a commitment to sustainability, issued a call for a campus sustainability rating system (pdf). The statement described a system that "would of necessity address all the dimensions of sustainability (health, social, economic and ecological) and all the sectors and functions of campus, including curriculum, facilities, operations, and collaboration with communities." HEASC called for "AASHE to convene all relevant stakeholders in a collaborative process to develop such a system."

Over the next year and a half, AASHE gathered feedback from workshop participants at several campus sustainability conferences and events. These discussions provided the groundwork for the first publicly available draft version, STARS 0.4 (pdf), released in September 2007. Experts from throughout the sustainability and higher education communities provided feedback on the draft system.

AASHE processed this feedback to develop the Pilot version of STARS, released in two phases in 2008. Nearly 70 colleges and universities participated in the pilot project. These institutions tested the system – from gathering data to reporting results – and provided extensive feedback about their experiences (pdf). While the pilot project was underway, AASHE released another draft version, STARS 0.5 (pdf), which again generated thoughtful feedback and suggestions (pdf) from diverse higher education stakeholders.

STARS 1.0 incorporated feedback, suggestions, and lessons learned from the three-year development process. STARS 1.1 and 1.2, the next two versions, incorporated minor substantive changes to the system based on needs from the higher education community.  While STARS is the most thoroughly vetted and extensively tested campus sustainability framework for higher education institutions, there is still plenty of room for improvement. To that end, we plan to continue improving the system over time. STARS 2.0, the current version of STARS, is intended to stimulate, not end, the conversation about how to measure and benchmark sustainability in higher education. AASHE welcomes your feedback and participation in continuing to refine and shape the system.

View a timeline showing the history and development of STARS.

fields.title: How do I estimate 2005 baseline data?
fields.content:
STARS includes four credits (OP 5: Greenhouse Gas Emissions Reduction, OP 7: Building Energy Consumption, OP 17: Waste Reduction, and OP 22: Water Consumption) that are based on comparing performance to a 2005 baseline year.

If an institution does not have 2005 data, it may either:

a) Estimate 2005 data using a trend line based on at least three years worth of data
b) Estimate conservatively (i.e., estimate that performance has not changed between the baseline and performance year). Following this approach, an institution would not be able to claim points during its first STARS submission, but would be able to use its previously estimated baseline for subsequent submissions.

Some of the 2005 baseline figures are based on multiple components. If an institution has data for some, but not all, of the components of the baseline figure, it may follow either of the approaches above to estimate the missing data and then combine it with the available data.

For example, the baseline for OP 17: Waste Reduction is based on the sum of garbage, recycling, and compost tonnage. If an institution had garbage data only for 2005, it could estimate recycling and compost weights and then add that to the garbage data to estimate the 2005 total.

fields.title: How should I provide feedback?
fields.content:
There are three main avenues for providing feedback:

1)  AASHE would appreciate responses to any or all of the questions outlined in this document (doc) by Monday, November 23.

2)  Throughout the testing process, please share any thoughts, concerns, and suggestions with AASHE by emailing stars@aashe.org.

3)  A survey will be given at the end of the Beta Testing period to capture final thoughts and feedback.

fields.title: My Resources
fields.content:
STARS Logo

Participants may wish to consult the STARS Brand Guidelines (pdf) for guidance on using the Charter Participant logo. 

Data Collection Tools

The STARS 1.0 Data Tracking Spreadsheet (xls) outlines the credits within each category and the reporting fields for each credit.  

Please note: This optional resource is provided to help organize your institution's data collection process; all data will need to be saved in the online Reporting Tool in order to report officially. Participants are encouraged to use the Reporting Tool throughout the data collection process. 

To facilitate the data collection process, a Word version of the STARS 1.0 credits (doc) is available for download. You may also download the PDF version of the complete Technical Manual (pdf).

STARS Update

The STARS Update is a free, monthly e-newsletter. Your subscription will keep you up to speed on the latest STARS news, resources, participant highlights, events, and more. Subscribe Today!

Institutional Resources

The following resources have been provided by STARS participants to share with other registered institutions.  To submit a resource to be posted here please contact stars@aashe.org.

California State University, Channel Islands
Provided by Laurel Replogle.

  • STARS Operations Category Tracking Spreadsheet (accdb)

San Diego State University
Provided by Sarah Campbell and Mariah Hudson.

  • STARS Faculty Survey Questions (doc)

University of California, San Diego
Provided by Maggie Souder.

  • STARS Contact Tracking Spreadsheet (xls)
  • STARS Education & Research Spreadsheet for Key Stakeholders (xls)
  • STARS Operations Spreadsheet for Key Stakeholders (xls)

Template Press Release

Template press release announcing STARS participation (doc)

Charter Participants may modify and use this press release template to announce their participation in STARS. 

Template Emails

Announcing STARS to Your Institution Email Template (doc)

The intention of this email template is to announce your institution's participation in STARS to campus stakeholders and notify these individuals that they may be contacted for information regarding the STARS credits.  

Colleague Outreach Email Template (doc)

Participants may modify this email template to connect with colleagues at other institutions that are not yet participating in the STARS program.  The Colleague Outreach Email Template details the benefits of the STARS program as well as the August 20, 2010 Charter Participant registration deadline.

Requesting Departmental Data for STARS Email Template (doc)

This email template was designed to assist STARS Liaisons in the data collection process and may be used to request information for specific STARS credits from campus stakeholders. 

STARS Overview Presentation

The STARS Overview Presentation (ppt) highlights the details of the STARS program.  Use this resource to share information about the STARS program with your institution. 

AASHE Campus Sustainability Resource Center

For more information and resources on sustainability efforts in higher education, please visit the AASHE Campus Sustainability Resource Center. The AASHE Campus Sustainability Resource Center is the home of many resources in the areas of publications, general sustainability, education & research, operations, and planning, administration & engagement.

Please note some of the resources in the AASHE Campus Sustainability Resource Center are locked, and therefore only available to AASHE member institutions with a valid AASHE account. For more information on AASHE membership, please visit the AASHE membership webpage.

fields.title: My Resources
fields.content:
STARS Visuals & Terms

Participants may wish to consult the STARS Brand Guidelines (pdf) for guidance on using the STARS logo and seals. 

View a list (pdf) of common STARS terms and definitions.

Data Collection Tools

The STARS 1.2 Data Tracking Spreadsheet (xls) outlines the credits within each category and the reporting fields for each credit. Data tracking spreadsheets for STARS 1.1.1 (xls) and STARS 1.0 (xls) are also available. Please note: This optional resource is provided to help organize your institution's data collection process; all data will need to be saved in the online Reporting Tool in order to report officially. Participants are encouraged to use the Reporting Tool throughout the data collection process. 

To facilitate the data collection process, Word versions of the STARS 1.2 (doc), STARS 1.1 Administrative Update One credits (doc), and the STARS 1.0 credits (doc) are available for download. You may also download the most recent version of the Technical Manual on the STARS website. Earlier versions are available on the website as well.

Template Emails

Announcing STARS to Your Institution Email Template (doc)

The intention of this email template is to announce your institution's participation in STARS to campus stakeholders and notify these individuals that they may be contacted for information regarding the STARS credits.  

Colleague Outreach Email Template (doc)

Participants may modify this email template to connect with colleagues at other institutions that are not yet participating in the STARS program.  The Colleague Outreach Email Template details the benefits of the STARS program and encourages registration.

Requesting Departmental Data for STARS Email Template (doc)

This email template was designed to assist STARS Liaisons in the data collection process and may be used to request information for specific STARS credits from campus stakeholders.

Responsible Party Email Template (doc)

AASHE recommends each Responsible Party listed in the STARS Reporting Tool is notified.  This email template gives a brief explanation of the STARS Program while also explaining the role of the individual that is identified as a Responsible Party.

Innovation Inventory

Innovation Inventory Process & Procedures (pdf)

This document details the processes and procedures for conducting the STARS Innovation Inventory, listed below.   

STARS Innovation Inventory 6.1.12 - (xls)

The STARS Innovation Inventory was created to effectively manage the large amount of information within the Innovation (IN) category of STARS. The current version of the inventory includes all STARS reports submitted through June 1, 2012.  

Additional Resources

The following resources have been provided by institutions considering participating in STARS, STARS Participants, and Partner Organizations. These resources were created in the context of a specific version of STARS, as indicated. Versions of the STARS Technical Manual vary, so you may find it necessary to adjust the resources slightly to align them with the version of STARS you are using. For additional resources on campus sustainability, visit AASHE's Campus Sustainability Resource Center. To submit a resource to be posted here please contact stars@aashe.org.

STARS Promotional Tools

The STARS Overview Presentation (pdf) highlights the details of the STARS program.  Use this resource to share information about the STARS program with your institution. 

The STARS Brochure (pdf) and STARS Flyer (pdf) are documents created by AASHE with the intention of sharing a brief snapshot of the STARS Program including benefits and how the program works.  Both resources may be shared with your colleagues, community members, and campus to communicate information about the STARS Program.

The STARS Flyer is a one-page document while the STARS Brochure is a two-page document where each page is intended to be printed back-to-back on a single sheet of paper and folded.  Please see the STARS Brochure printing instructions (pdf).

Stay Connected

Subscribe to the AASHE newsletters to stay connected to the most current information on sustainability in higher education, including STARS.

fields.title: Public Comment Period: Proposed Changes
fields.content:
Welcome to the public comment period for STARS 2.0. This is the first major update of STARS since the release of the original STARS 1.0 Technical Manual in January 2010.  The STARS 2.0 Technical Manual: Draft for Public Comment was created based on careful consideration of the feedback from you, the higher education community, STARS Technical Advisors, and the STARS Steering Committee. We welcome and look forward to your comments, and want to thank you for being part of our engaged community. 

An overview of the proposed changes to the STARS 2.0 Technical Manual: Draft for Public Comment is outlined below.  Important documents and steps outlining how to submit feedback are included in "Public Comment Period: Participation." Answers to common inquiries may be found in "Public Comment Period: FAQs." 

The STARS 2.0 Public Comment Period will be open from Monday, October 8 through Friday, November 30, 2012.  Feedback will not be considered outside of this timeframe.  However, questions and comments about specific STARS credits or the overall program may always be emailed to stars@aashe.org.

Overview 

The proposed changes for the draft of STARS 2.0 are considered Major Substantive Changes.  Proposed changes for the draft of STARS 2.0 include:

  • This proposed draft  includes a single tier of 70 credits, reduced from 139 in STARS 1.2.
  • New credits have been added, including credits covering student-run co-curricular programs, projects that utilize the campus as a living laboratory, air pollutant emissions, land use, biodiversity, wastewater treatment, workplace health and safety, and community stakeholder engagement.
  • Former Tier Two credits have been consolidated into new credits and into existing credits as optional reporting fields.
  • Credit titles have been simplified where possible.
  • Minor edits have been made throughout to address inconsistencies (e.g. in reporting field language), provide additional guidance and clarification based on participant feedback, and correct typos and formatting issues.
  • New standards and terms have been added throughout, as well as additional links to useful resources.
  • New fields have been added to each subcategory and to the Innovation credits to allow institutions to upload images associated with STARS subcategories.
  • The criteria for some credits have been altered significantly to reflect participant feedback, Technical Advisor discussions, and developments in the field (for example the Food and Beverage Purchasing, Affordability and Access, and Employee Compensation credits).
  • Additional normalization factors have been added to some credits, for example the GHG Emissions, Energy Consumption, and Water Use. Credits are normalized by both weighted campus users and gross square feet of building space.
  • The use of baselines in STARS has been changed significantly to give granting institutions greater flexibility in setting baselines for GHG emissions, energy consumption, waste generation and water use.
  • Performance thresholds have been introduced into several credits to complement the use of baselines. Points are awarded for these credits based on a combination of reductions from baselines and performance in relation to minimum thresholds and performance targets.

For more information about the Technical Development process please see the STARS Technical Development Policy (pdf) or visit the STARS Policies page of the STARS website.

Visualization of Changes by Category

This visual illustrates the proposed changes to the titles and arrangement of the sub-categories within each STARS Category.

fields.title: Register for STARS
fields.content:
With the launch of STARS 2.0, AASHE is excited to announce different levels of access that will dramatically improve the ease of campus sustainability reporting worldwide. These levels of access are based on participant feedback, and will allow institutions to report and share their campus sustainability data.

 

Full Access

For 12 months*
  •   Register
  • $1,400
  • $500 discount for AASHE members

Basic Access

 
  •   Register
  • No Cost
  •  

 

Benefits Full Access Basic Access
Measure your institution’s current sustainability performance    
Create a baseline for continuous improvement toward sustainability    
Streamline your sustainability reporting efforts by sharing STARS reporting data with other organizations (e.g. Sierra Magazine and The Princeton Review)    
Compare and learn from other institutions of similar type and demographic    
Gain global recognition for your sustainability efforts as a STARS rated institution    
Celebrate your rating with access to STARS promotional tools    
Monitor your progress toward a STARS rating with automated point calculation    
Excel and PDF exports of STARS data    
Access to all public STARS data through the STARS API    

*Institutions that purchase a STARS subscription within 90 days after their previous subscription has expired are eligible for a 50% discount.

Global Access – After a successful pilot period, institutions outside of U.S. and Canada are now able to register for basic and full access to STARS.

Top 5 Reasons to Register

As heard from STARS Participants:

  1. “The biggest benefit of STARS was that it has generated new ideas. Given that STARS is so widely used, the credits we were not able to attain are looked at as suggestions that we hope to implement in the future.”
  2. “It has opened lines of communication and has expanded sustainability understanding across campus.”
  3. “It is a great benefit to have a uniform method for recording and reporting data regularly.
  4. “Due to administrative changes at the institution, it was very difficult to generate momentum and interest, however, the results of the data collection will be used to draft a Sustainability Strategic Plan which will fulfill the requirements of the College Strategic Plan.”
  5. “The most important benefit was pedagogical. We look forward to continuing to use STARS as a central part of our environmental studies and sustainability capstone courses.”

How do recent changes affect me?

My institution is already participating in STARS.
Institutions that have a current STARS subscription will not need to re-register. An institution with a STARS subscription will retain all the benefits above.

My institution previously used is already using the Campus Sustainability Data Collector.
An institution with an expired STARS subscription, or one previously using the CSDC, will retain Basic Access to the STARS Reporting Tool and also have the option to submit their data as a STARS Reporter. Institutions with Basic Access to the STARS Reporting Tool will have the option to purchase a subscription for Full Access at any time.

My institution is an International Pilot Participant.
All STARS International Pilot Participants will automatically be registered as STARS Participants under the Basic Access option and will have the option to share their data publicly as STARS Reporters. Global participants may purchase a Full Access STARS subscription at any time. 

Not sure where your institution currently stands with STARS? Complete the Eligibility Inquiry Form and you'll receive a response from the AASHE staff. All other inquiries about STARS may be directed to stars@aashe.org.

fields.title: Reporting Process
fields.content:
Getting started in the STARS Reporting Tool is simple.  Any individual that is listed as a 'user' in the STARS Reporting Tool has access and may log-in with an AASHE Account. Not listed as a 'user'? Contact your institution's STARS Liaison or send an email to stars@aashe.org.

Once you've logged into the STARS Reporting Tool, start by completing the Institutional Characteristics section.  Then, determine if a version migration or data migration makes sense for your institution.  Next, document data in the appropriate fields for each STARS credit. After a final review you'll be ready to learn more about the submission process.

Institutional Characteristics 

This section requests three types of data. For example: 

  1. Defining an institution’s boundary for reporting purposes – If an institution owns a hospital, are its operational and academic attributes included in STARS?
  2. Operational characteristics – How much of an institution’s gross floor area is laboratory space?
  3. Demographics and academics – What proportion of student FTE enrollment is residential full-time students?

Consolidation of institutional characteristics data into a single section within STARS provides the following benefits:

  • Institutions using STARS can review data in this section to facilitate the identification of peer institutions for benchmarking purposes (data from this section may be used to create a new STARS benchmarking tool on the website).
  • Placing operational characteristics and demographics into a single section will promote data accuracy (Errors in these areas represent the majority of STARS data accuracy issues). Institutions can verify their own data in one location, and potential errors can be spotted more easily by third parties.
  • Several values in the Institutional Characteristics section are required to pursue one or more STARS credits. With the launch of STARS 2.0, the STARS Reporting Tool will feature an auto-population option that will streamline reporting by bringing these values into other areas of the report when relevant.

Manage Data

Registered under a certain version of STARS when a new version is launched and want to switch version? Interested in working from a previously saved dataset instead of documenting data in the Reporting Tool from scratch? No problem.  

'Version Upgrades' allow you to upgrade to the most current version of STARS. 'Data Migration' allows you to pull previously saved data sets into the report you are working on (in the 'My Submission' section of the STARS Reporting Tool). For detailed information, visit the 'Manage Data' tab in the 'My Summary' section of the STARS Reporting Tool. 

Documenting Data

Each credit in the STARS Reporting Tool will ask for information in the following sections:

Reporting Fields
Reporting Fields in the STARS Reporting Tool are the spaces where you will submit data for the information requested in the 'Reporting Fields' section of the STARS Technical Manual.  Fields with a red asterisk are required, while those with a blue asterisk are conditionally required. 

Notes
Any supplemental information that you'd like to share publicly in your institution's STARS Report that is related to the credit, but doesn't fit in the Reporting Fields, may be documented in the 'Notes' section.  

An 'Internal Notes' tab is available in each credit in the STARS Reporting Tool as well.  This section may be used to share notes in the Reporting Tool that are not shared publicly outside of the Reporting Tool.

Responsible Party
As a data accuracy measure, AASHE asks that a single Responsible Party is documented for each STARS credit.  The individual should be the most appropriate person to direct questions regarding the data document in the credit, not the individual entering data into the STARS Reporting Tool for the specific credit.

Submission Status
These statuses are provided to help you manage the STARS submission process. You may return to any credit and update its status until the final submission is completed.

  • 'Pursuing' requires that all of the required fields have been completed. 
  • 'In Progress' indicates that you are still editing a credit. Please note that this status refers to an individual being 'In Progress' of documenting information for the credit; not that the project or program the credit is asking about is 'In Progress.' 
  • 'Not Pursuing' indicates that you do not wish to submit data for a credit. When the final submission is made public, only the 'Notes' field for credits with this status will be made public. Institutions will not earn points for credits marked as 'Not Pursuing.' 

If you would only like the notes section of the credit to be visible to the public, you may choose 'Not Pursuing' for the credit. 

Continuous Access & Sharing Data

All institutions that subscribe to STARS will have continuous access to update data in the STARS Reporting Tool.  Those STARS Participants that wish to share data with organizations such as Sierra magazine and The Princeton Review may do so by following the instructions in the 'Share Data' tab in the 'My Summary' section of the STARS Reporting Tool.

fields.title: Share Your Story
fields.content:
Congratulations!  You've navigated through STARS, collected data, documented it, and submitted a completed STARS Report. What’s next?

Take Action

AASHE encourages all STARS participants to learn from their STARS Reports. Utilize the STARS Data Displays to benchmark with peers and thoroughly review your institution's STARS Report to learn which sustainability efforts on your campus are successful, as well as identify areas of improvement. Your comprehensive STARS Report is a great guide to help organize future sustainability programming and prioritize efforts that will have the largest impact. 

Showcase Your Efforts

Here are a just a few examples of the many efforts you can take to highlight your achievement and gain recognition.

  • Show off your newly earned STARS seal - Navigate to the ‘My Resources’ section of the STARS Reporting Tool to download the STARS seal and brand guidelines.  Share your campus’ achievement by posting the STARS seal to your campus website, sustainability website, relevant newsletters, email signatures, and other visible locations.
  • Share STARS with campus stakeholders - Contact all of the individuals that helped you complete STARS, thank them for their efforts, share the link to your institution’s STARS Report, and work together on ways to enhance sustainability initiatives in their area of campus.
  • Create a communication plan  - Connect with your campus’ marketing and communications offices and design a strategy to gain recognition for your achievement with the campus and surrounding community.  A template press release is available for your use in the ‘My Resources’ section of the STARS Reporting Tool.
  • Use STARS as a recruitment tool - Highlight your achievement when connecting with potential new students and their parents to illustrate your campus’ commitment to sustainability. 

Shape the System

Throughout the STARS process AASHE encourages feedback from its participants.  Now that your institution's STARS Report is complete, we encourage you more than ever to share questions and feedback to help shape the system.  We take your comments very seriously - every phone call and email is documented and and every suggestion for improvement is considered in developing future versions of STARS. 

Interested in being more involved in the development of STARS?  Familiarize yourself with our Governance structure and stay tuned to the AASHE Bulletin for calls for STARS Technical Advisors and Steering Committee members.

What People are Saying

Has your institution been recognized in campus, local, or national media due to it’s participation in STARS?  If so, let us know and we’ll highlight the article on our Media Coverage page.

fields.title: Stars 2.0
fields.content: This is where 2.0 Content goes

fields.title: STARS 2.0 Preview
fields.content:
Where do you stand in the higher education sustainability landscape? Establish a baseline with STARS 2.0.

The most comprehensive and streamlined version to date, STARS 2.0 is a new and improved way to:

  • measure your institution’s sustainability performance
  • learn from other institutions of similar types and demographics
  • create a baseline for continuous improvement
  • foster cross-campus collaboration and buy-in for your sustainability efforts
  • celebrate and gain recognition for your sustainability wins and innovations

You spoke. We took action.

STARS 2.0 is the result of feedback from STARS Participants and the larger AASHE community about how the process can be most valuable to you and your campus. In this version, we’ve addressed common concerns and added exciting new features. For a detailed look at the changes that led to 2.0, visit these resources:

  • STARS 2.0 Technical Manual
  • STARS 2.0 Summary of Changes | Administrative Update One
  • STARS 2.0 Credit Checklist
  • STARS Public Comment Feedback
  • STARS 2013 Annual Review
  • August 27 “Everything You Need to Know About STARS 2.0” webinar

NOTE: Participants that downloaded the pre-launch version of the STARS 2.0 Technical Manual (August 2013) should download the latest version (October 2013) that includes administrative updates (pdf).

Created by higher education for higher education.

AASHE’s Sustainability Tracking, Assessment & Rating System™ (STARS) is a transparent, self-reporting framework for colleges and universities to measure their sustainability performance. Get started with STARS by viewing the newly updated website, stars.aashe.org.

fields.title: STARS Overview
fields.content:
The Sustainability Tracking, Assessment & Rating System™ (STARS®) is a transparent, self-reporting framework for colleges and universities to measure their sustainability performance. STARS is intended to engage and recognize the full spectrum of colleges and universities—from community colleges to research universities, and from institutions just starting their sustainability programs to long-time campus sustainability leaders. STARS encompasses long-term sustainability goals for already high-achieving institutions as well as entry points of recognition for institutions that are taking first steps toward sustainability. STARS is designed to:

  • Provide a framework for understanding sustainability in all sectors of higher education.
  • Enable meaningful comparisons over time and across institutions using a common set of measurements developed with broad participation from the campus sustainability community.
  • Create incentives for continual improvement toward sustainability.
  • Facilitate information sharing about higher education sustainability practices and performance.
  • Build a stronger, more diverse campus sustainability community.

The current version of STARS incorporates feedback, suggestions, and lessons learned since the launch of STARS 1.0 in January 2010. While STARS is the most thoroughly vetted and extensively tested campus sustainability framework for colleges and universities, it is by no means perfect. The current version of STARS is intended to stimulate, not end, the conversation about how to measure and benchmark sustainability in higher education. AASHE welcomes your feedback and participation in continuing to refine and shape the system. To learn more view our Technical Development Policy or submit your inquiries about STARS to stars@aashe.org.

For additional information about the history of STARS, please view archived versions of STARS, webinars, publications, and media coverage.

fields.title: STARS Pilot Project
fields.content:
STARS Pilot Project
Institutions Participating in the STARS Pilot
STARS Pilot Project Conference Calls

Approach

The STARS pilot project took place from February 2008 to January 2009. Institutions that participated in the pilot tested the system and provided feedback to AASHE to help shape future versions of STARS. 

The STARS pilot project took place in two phases. A phased approach helped to moderate the workload for participating institutions. It also allowed AASHE to solicit another round of feedback about some sections included in STARS before asking schools to gather data.

Phase One of the STARS pilot started in February 2008. Phase One covers the Operations category and about half of the Administration and Finance category. View STARS Guide to Pilot Phase One (pdf). 

STARS Pilot Phase Two started in September 2008.  Phase Two covers the Education and Research category and remaining credits in the Administration and Finance category, as well as Tier Two Credits and Innovation Credits.  View STARS Guide to Pilot Phase Two (pdf).

Results

The Sustainability Tracking, Assessment & Rating System Pilot Project Results (pdf) is a detailed summary of results and feedback received during the pilot project.

Student Research

Kyle Murphy, a student at The Evergreen State College, coordinated his institution's participation in the STARS Pilot Project and wrote his Master's thesis about lessons learned from that experience.  He writes:

This research focused on three main questions with respect to Evergreen’s use of the STARS tool: (a) Is STARS an effective tool for use at Evergreen (did the framework address issues important to Evergreen, did it meet the criteria of an ideal assessment framework, and what are the advantages and disadvantages), (b) Does the STARS process lead to organizational learning, and (c) What STARS reveal about Evergreen’s commitment to sustainability. Using a case study research design, I took a multi-disciplinary approach to the data collection for STARS implementation. Through my research I found that STARS is an effective tool to evaluate sustainability at Evergreen, which led to organizational learning, and highlighted Evergreen’s complex and dynamic commitment to sustainability.

Thesis presentation (pdf)
Thesis full text (pdf)

fields.title: STARS Policies
fields.content:
As AASHE has received comments, suggestions, and questions from STARS participants and unique circumstances have come to light, there has been a need to develop policies to address various issues in STARS. Policies that directly affect STARS participants are provided below.

STARS Eligibility Policy

Any college or university in the United States or Canada may participate in STARS. An institution is defined by having a separate and distinct administration (e.g. president or chancellor). For institutions that may be a part of a larger system, they must have an administration that is separate and distinct from others in the system of which it is a part. The complete Eligibility Requirements for STARS Policy is available on the STARS Steering Committee webpage.

If an institution or entity does not meet these requirements but you believe there is a compelling case for the participation of that institution or entity in STARS, please complete the Eligibility Enquiry Form. This information will be evaluated by the STARS staff, who will decide if the institution or entity is eligible to participate in STARS.

Correcting Mistakes in a STARS Submission Policy

If an institution realizes it has made a mistake when documenting information in the STARS Reporting Tool, after the information has been submitted for a STARS Rating and is public on the STARS website, the STARS Liaison may correct this information by completing a STARS Data Change Request Form (LINK). This form, available in the STARS Reporting Tool, will then be submitted to the STARS team for review prior to the information being corrected in the institution’s STARS Report. The corrected information in the institution’s STARS Report will include a date stamp and note that explains the reason for the change and will be publicly available. The details of this process are explained in the Correcting Mistakes in the Reporting Tool Policy.

The process for making corrections to an institution’s STARS Report will be the same even if the change results in a new rating level. An institution may make corrections to its STARS Report with no charge up to a year after the STARS submission is received by AASHE. After that time, any institution-requested corrections require a small processing fee of $150 per correction.

STARS Submission Accuracy Inquiry Policy

The information in an institution's STARS Report is self-reported and is not verified by AASHE or a third party. The STARS Submission Accuracy Inquiry Form is available for individuals who wish to report erroneous data they have discovered within an institution’s STARS Report. Once the form has been completed and submitted, the individual’s comments will be sent directly to the STARS Liaison of the institution in question. In accordance with the STARS Submission Review Policy, the STARS Team encourages the individual with a concern and the STARS Liaison of the institution in question to resolve the issue. If direct communication between these two parties does not resolve the issue, a STARS staff member will evaluate the STARS submission accuracy inquiry and guide them through the next steps in the process.

STARS Technical Development Policy

Because STARS seeks continuous improvement, while balancing the needs of our users, our Steering Committee has adopted a Technical Development Policy to guide how new information will be incorporated into STARS. Administrative changes will be made no more than quarterly; minor substantive changes will be made no more often than annually; and major revisions will be made no more often than bi-annually.

fields.title: Submission Process
fields.content:
In order to have your institution's completed STARS Report publicly available on the website and to earn a STARS rating, you must first complete the three steps of the STARS submission process.

1. Review & Submit

If you haven’t done so already, finalize the data requested in the Institutional Characteristics section of the STARS Reporting Tool.  This section requests three types of data:

  1. Defining an institution’s boundary for reporting purposes – For example, if an institution owns a hospital, are its operational and academic attributes included in STARS?
  2. Operational characteristics – For example, how much of an institution’s gross floor area is laboratory space?
  3. Demographics and academics – For example, what proportion of student FTE enrollment is residential full-time students?

In addition to finalizing the Institutional Characteristics, in this step of the submission process you will be able to see all of the credits in the STARS Reporting Tool that were left blank or marked as 'In Progress' and determine if any last minute changes need to be made to these credits.  

2. President’s Letter & STARS Reporter Option

A letter from the institution’s highest ranking executive, usually a President or Chancellor, is required to sign a letter stating all of the information in the STARS Report is accurate and up-to-date. This letter may also serve as a cover letter to the institution's STARS Report providing additional information about sustainability initiatives on your campus.

Please note: Acquiring a letter from the president may take some time. AASHE encourages institutions to notify the president's office about this submission requirement several months prior to the submission deadline.

Also in this second step of the submission process institutions with Full Access to the STARS Reporting Tool may choose to submit your institution’s STARS Report as a STARS Reporter or under the provisional rating it has achieved (STARS Bronze, Silver, Gold, or Platinum). Institutions that do not earn enough points to be awarded a STARS Bronze rating will automatically achieve the STARS Reporter status upon submission.

3. Confirmation

The final step of the submission process is to confirm that the information documented in the STARS Reporting Tool is ready to be submitted for a STARS rating.  Upon completion of the submission process your institution’s STARS Report will be public on the STARS website, the STARS Liaison and Executive Contact will receive a confirmation email with next steps, and after a quick review an e-certificate of appreciation will be sent to the highest ranking executive.

Please note:  After the submission process is complete you may not add any additional information to your institution’s public STARS Report.  However, a Data Correction Request may be submitted if a mistake needs to be corrected.

fields.title: What should I look for?  What am I testing?
fields.content:
As a Beta Tester, you will have an opportunity to enter data into the STARS Reporting Tool and provide AASHE with feedback on how to make the tool easy to use.  This includes spotting any errors or bugs with the site and making recommendations for how to improve the overall experience. 

Although fabricated data are acceptable during the testing period, we encourage Beta Testers to get started with their actual submission and use real data. Data submitted during the Beta testing period will carry over in your account when the Reporting Tool launches in January.

AASHE will continue building the Reporting Tool and fixing bugs during this period, so the look of the site and minor features may change. We'll keep you updated if there are any additional changes you should know about throughout the Beta Testing phase.
fields.teaser: As a Beta Tester, you will have an opportunity to enter data into the STARS Reporting Tool and provide AASHE with feedback on how to make the tool easy to use.  This includes spotting any errors or bugs with the site and making recommendations for how to improve the overall experience.

fields.title: When does the Beta Testing period conclude?
fields.content:
Providing feedback early will allow AASHE time to incorporate suggestions and changes to the site before launching the tool widely in January.  With that in mind, please provide responses to these questions by November 23.  

The Beta testing period will run through January 11, 2010. At that time, this site will close and you will not be able to enter additional data until the Reporting Tool launches widely later that month. Although additional data will not be able to be entered after January 11, 2010, you may still submit feedback to STARS on the Reporting Tool.
fields.teaser: Providing feedback early will allow AASHE time to incorporate suggestions and changes to the site before launching the tool widely in January.  With that in mind, please provide responses to these questions by November 23.

fields.title: Public Comment Period: Participation
fields.content:
Any individual is welcome to participate in the STARS 2.0 Public Comment Period.  Individuals do not need to be affiliated with an AASHE member or STARS Participant institution to share feedback. Feedback may be submitted on behalf of an individual, an institution, an organization, or a business. All individuals and organizations submitting comments on specific credits or STARS subcategories must do so through the Public Comment Form which is linked below.

AASHE recommends reading through the content of this web page, including the important documents below, prior to submitting comments.

An overview of the proposed changes to the STARS 2.0 Technical Manual: Draft for Public Comment may be found in "Public Comment Period: Proposed Changes." Answers to common inquiries may be found in "Public Comment Period: FAQs." 

Step 1: Review Key Documents

STARS 2.0 Vision Statement
The 2.0 Vision Statement was publicly posted in January 2012 and intended to respond to the many comments and suggestions that staff and STARS Steering Committee members have heard from the campus sustainability community prior to that time about STARS.

Technical Development Policy
STARS seeks continuous improvement, while balancing the needs of our users.  As a result, the STARS Steering Committee has adopted a Technical Development Policy to guide how new information will be incorporated into STARS.

Summary of Proposed Changes
The summary of proposed changes (pdf) is a 6-page document that provides an “at-a-glance” overview of the major changes being proposed for STARS 2.0.  The overview of major changes, edits to the introduction, and updates to the Innovation Category of the STARS Technical Manual are highlighted first.  Then, the document breaks down the proposed changes to each STARS Category, sub-category, and credit where appropriate.

Proposed STARS 2.0 Technical Manual
Two versions of the STARS 2.0 Technical Manual: Draft for Public Comment are provided below.  The first is a “clean version” which implements all the proposed changes.

The “tracked changes version” of the draft of the STARS 2.0 Technical Manual: Draft for Public Comment includes tracked changes that reflect the exact edits made to the STARS 1.2 Technical Manual that resulted in the clean version of the draft.

  • STARS 2.0 Technical Manual: Draft for Public Comment (Clean Version) (pdf)
  • STARS 2.0 Technical Manual: Draft for Public Comment (Tracked Changes Version) (pdf)

Please note that the STARS 2.0 Technical Manual: Draft for Public Comment is lengthy.  Please plan accordingly so that all feedback is submitted through the public comment form between Monday, October 8 and Friday, November 30, 2012. All comments received will be carefully considered as part of the STARS 2.0 technical development process and shared publicly after the conclusion of the public comment period.

Step 2: Submit Feedback

The Public Comment Form is the vehicle to use to submit comments to AASHE concerning proposed changes at the credit and subcategory level in the STARS 2.0 Technical Manual: Draft for Public Comment.

Step 3: Complete Survey

AASHE asks that individuals participating in the STARS 2.0 Public Comment Period complete the STARS 2.0 System-Wide Issues Survey. This survey covers system-wide issues, including category weighting, scoring methodologies, and data verification in STARS. The survey consists of six multiple choice questions and should take no longer than 15 minutes to complete. The survey results will help inform the remainder of the STARS 2.0 development process.

fields.title: Public Comment Period: FAQs
fields.content:
What was AASHE’s process for making changes to the STARS Technical Manual between STARS 1.2 and STARS 2.0?
How do I participate?
Who can participate?
How long is the public comment period?
What happens to my comments once they are submitted?
What are next steps after the public comment period?
When will STARS 2.0 be launched?
Will there be changes to the STARS Reporting Tool with the launch of STARS 2.0?
Who should I contact with questions?
Will my STARS 1.2 data migrate into 2.0?

What was AASHE’s process for making changes to the STARS Technical Manual between STARS 1.2 and STARS 2.0?
All feedback on ways to strengthen the STARS Technical Manual, and the overall STARS program, are taken into careful consideration by the AASHE staff.  Credit-specific feedback is shared with the STARS Technical Advisors for consideration when making enhancements to the STARS credits.  Edits to the STARS credits are reviewed and subject to approval by the STARS Steering Committee.  
 
For more information about the Technical Development process please see the STARS Technical Development Policy (pdf) or visit the STARS Policies page of the STARS website.

How do I participate?
All individuals submitting comments must do so through the Public Comment Form. AASHE recommends reading through the content of the Public Comment Period: Proposed Changes and Public Comment Period: Participation webpages prior to participating in the public comment period.

If you or your organization have more extensive comments (e.g. longer than 3,000 characters) or wish to submit a letter or other document, please email stars@aashe.org.

Who can participate?
Any individual is welcome to participate in the STARS 2.0 Public Comment Period.  Individuals do not need to be affiliated with an AASHE member or STARS Participant institution to share feedback. Feedback may be submitted on behalf of an individual, an institution, an organization, or a business.

If you or your organization have more extensive comments (e.g. longer than 3,000 characters) or wish to submit a letter or other document, please email stars@aashe.org.

How long is the public comment period?
The STARS 2.0 Public Comment Period will take place from Monday, October 8 through Friday, November 30, 2012.  Feedback will not be considered outside of this timeframe.  However, questions and comments about the specific STARS credit or overall program may always be emailed to stars@aashe.org.

What happens to my comments once they are submitted?
All comments received will be carefully considered as part of the STARS 2.0 technical development process and shared publicly on the STARS website after the conclusion of the public comment period.

What are next steps after the public comment period?
Once the public comment period closes, all comments, survey responses and other feedback received will be taken into consideration by AASHE staff. Recommendations for revisions will be sent to the STARS Steering Committee. The STARS 2.0 Technical Manual will be finalized upon approval by the Steering Committee and a release date for STARS 2.0 will be announced.

For more information about the Technical Development process please see the STARS Technical Development Policy (pdf) or visit the STARS Policies page of the STARS website.

When will STARS 2.0 be launched?
AASHE anticipates that the STARS 2.0 Technical Manual will be available to the public sometime in 2013. However, no specific date has been designated at this time.

Will there be changes to the STARS Reporting Tool with the launch of STARS 2.0?
Yes, in addition to an updated STARS Technical Manual, AASHE will also be making enhancements to the STARS Reporting Tool.  These enhancements are currently being finalized by the AASHE staff, but will be designed to increase the functionality and user experience when working in the STARS Reporting Tool.

Who should I contact with questions?
All questions relating to STARS may be emailed to stars@aashe.org.

Will my STARS 1.2 data migrate into 2.0?
Institutions are responsible for reporting on the STARS Technical Manual that they register under. Therefore, if your institution registers when STARS 1.2 is the most up-to-date version of the STARS Technical Manual, it is under this version that it will to submit a STARS Report. However, if your institution has an active subscription to the STARS Reporting Tool when STARS 2.0 is launched, it will have the option to migrate its data to the most up-to-date version of STARS.

Please see the Reporting and Information Sharing FAQs for details about migrating data.
