fields.title: Reporting
fields.content:
All STARS reporting will be done using the online Reporting Tool, which is only available to current STARS Participants. The STARS Technical Manual is publicly available and provides the information necessary to gather the data required for STARS. The descriptions of the STARS credits in the Technical Manual include the following:

  • Credit Rationale–provides background on the importance of the credit in the context of sustainability.
  • Criteria–describes how an institution earns points for the credit.
  • Applicability–indicates which institutions’ STARS Ratings will be affected by their responses to the credit. Some credits do not apply to some types of institutions. For example, credits involving residence halls do not apply to institutions that do not have residence halls.
  • Scoring–explains how points are allocated for the credit.
  • Reporting Fields–lists the fields that appear within the Reporting Tool for each credit. Some fields are required while others are listed as optional if the institution wishes to provide additional information.
  • Timeframe–describes the time period from which data should be drawn. For some credits, particularly those that are based on the presence of a policy or program, institutions should report on current practices (i.e. status at the time of reporting). Other credits, particularly those based on quantitative performance, require historical performance data, typically drawn from a one-year period.
  • Sampling and Data Standards–provides guidelines on when institutions may use a representative sample to measure performance and when samples are prohibited.

Additionally, a step-by-step guide to the details of the entire STARS process, from registration to submission, is also provided within the STARS website. 

Institutional Boundary

Each institution is expected to include its entire main campus when collecting data. Institutions may choose to include any other land holdings, facilities, farms, and satellite campuses, as long as the selected boundary is the same for every credit. Institutions will specify the boundary for included data in the institutional information section of the Reporting Tool. If an institution finds it necessary to exclude a particular unit from its submission, the reason for excluding it must be provided in the notes accompanying the submitted data.

Supplemental Data

STARS Participants reporting under STARS 1.2, or future versions of STARS, will be able to share the information documented for each STARS credit in the STARS Reporting Tool with the Princeton Review and Sierra magazine, if they choose to do so. In addition, there are some data points, not included in STARS, which these organizations are also interested in, that AASHE has identified as supplemental data in the reporting process. Any information documented in the supplemental section does not impact a STARS rating and will not be posted publicly in an institution’s STARS Report. Completing these fields is optional but important if your institution would like to be included in Princeton Review Green Rating and/or American’s Coolest Schools.

Once your institution has completed documenting its data in the STARS Reporting Tool, it will have the option to allow other organizations to have access to this information for use in their publications. To allow access, STARS Participants much indicate which organization data will be shared with and save a snapshot of data to be shared.  Instructions for taking and sharing snapshots of data are outlined in the “Share Data” tab in the “My Summary” section of the STARS Reporting Tool. Though all STARS information becomes public, sharing your institution’s data in this manner allows these organizations to gain access to the data in a user-friendly manner that is easy to analyze. Please note, the Princeton Review and Sierra magazine may not use all of the data shared.

Your institution must take a snapshot of its data and share this information to be considered for another organizations' publications. Instructions for taking and sharing snapshots of data are outlined in the "Share Data" tab of the "My Summary" section in the STARS Reporting Tool.

Submission Process

Once an institution has completed documenting all of the required data in the STARS Reporting Tool it may submit this data for a STARS Rating. The process for finalizing a STARS submission involves three steps.

Step 1: The institution will have the opportunity to edit the institutional boundary that was designated when the institution first started the STARS process. In addition, the institution will be able to see all of the credits in the STARS Reporting Tool that were left blank or marked as "in progress" and determine if any last minute changes need to be made to these credits. 

Step 2: At this time the institution will upload the President's Letter which states that all of the information in the STARS submission is accurate and up-to-date.  This letter may also serve as a cover letter to the institution's STARS Report.  Please note that since acquiring a letter from the president may take some time, AASHE encourages institutions to begin work with the president's office several months prior to the submission deadline. Also, the institution may choose if it would like to submit its STARS data as a STARS Reporter or under the provisional rating it has achieved (STARS Bronze, Silver, Gold, or Platinum). Institutions that have earned less than 24 points will automatically achieve the STARS Reporter rating.

Step 3: The institution will confirm that the information documented in the STARS Reporting Tool is ready to be submitted for a STARS rating.

Please note, once information is submitted for a STARS rating the institution's STARS Report will be publicly available on the STARS website. Also, at this time, the institution may not add any additional information to its public STARS Report.  However, a Data Correction Request may be submitted if an institution realizes it has made a mistake when documenting information in the STARS Reporting Tool after the information has been submitted for a STARS Rating and is public on the STARS website.
fields.teaser: All STARS reporting will be done using the online Reporting Tool, which is only available to current STARS Participants. The STARS Technical Manual is publicly available and provides the information necessary to gather the data required for STARS.

fields.title: Getting Started
fields.content:
Whether you’re new to STARS or a returning Participant, AASHE recommends taking a few steps before you dive into data documentation:

  1. Download the STARS Technical Manual and review the STARS credits
  2. Determine an approach to data collection (see below)
  3. Identify your data collection team 
  4. Familiarize yourself with the Reporting Process
  5. Review the requirements of the Submission Process

STARS Participants may access additional resources including data collection tools, STARS seals, and template press releases, in the 'My Resources' section of the STARS Reporting Tool.

Get Organized, Collect Data

There are several different approaches to collecting STARS data.  Which option is best for your campus?  If your data collection team is outside of these examples, please let us know at stars@aashe.org.

  1. The sustainability champion - a single energetic individual that leads the organization of STARS on their campus, including: data collection, documentation, submission, and post-submission marketing and communication.
  2. A sustainability office or committee - a group of diverse campus stakeholders that divide the data collection by the categories and subcategories of the STARS Technical Manual.
  3. STARS courses - usually lead by an enthusiastic faculty person, courses may be created to focuses solely on STARS or STARS may be integrated into an existing course.  
  4. Individual student projects - this option has taken different forms, such as a graduate student thesis project or the focus of a student intern for course credit.

Resources

The STARS Brochure (pdf) and STARS Flyer (pdf) are documents created by AASHE with the intention of sharing a brief snapshot of STARS including benefits and how the program works.  Both resources may be shared with your colleagues, community members, and campus to communicate information about STARS.

The STARS Flyer is a one-page document while the STARS Brochure is a two-page document where each page is intended to be printed back-to-back on a single sheet of paper and folded.  Please see the STARS Brochure printing instructions (pdf).

 

 

The STARS Overview Presentation (ppt | pdf) highlights the details of STARS.  Use this resource to share information about STARS with your institution.

fields.title: How to Use the STARS Reporting Tool
fields.content:
Step 1: Log in

To access the STARS Reporting Tool, log in to the STARS website by entering your email address and password associated with your AASHE Account (i.e., the account you use to access AASHE’s Resource Center). If you have lost or forgotten your AASHE password, you may re-set it here. If you do not have an AASHE Account, you may create one here.

Please note: only the individual who registered the institution will be able to log in initially. To grant additional users access to the Tool, the individual who registered the institution should log in, choose the "Manage Institution" link, and click on the "Users" tab.

Step 2:  Access the Reporting Tool

Follow the Reporting Tool link at the top right of the STARS website to get started.

Step 3: Enter Data

To begin entering data, select “My Submission” from the menu.  This takes you to a summary page that provides an overview of your progress. From the summary page, you may select the category or credit for which you’d like to begin entering information.

Step 4: Submit for a Rating

Once you have completed entering data into the Reporting Tool you may submit the data for a STARS rating.  Under "My Submission" select "Submit for a Rating" in the status table on the top of the page. 

 

For additional resources on using the STARS Reporting Tool, please see the STARS Reporting Tool 101 webinar archive.
fields.teaser: Step 1: Log in

fields.title: Participants & Reports
fields.content: Combine "Current Participants" and "Rated Institutions" on existing STARS website into a single "Participants and Reports."  All subscribed institutions are listed and those that have submitted a STARS Report are linked.  Should be able to sort the list (which will be large) by version, submission date, and level of recognition.

fields.title: Previous Publications
fields.content:
STARS Quarterly Review

In 2012, AASHE published STARS data in a quarterly format, through the STARS Quarterly Review (SQR). Each edition of the SQR tells a story of sustainability in higher education based on data submitted in STARS Reports. AASHE expects to publish an annual STARS report in late-summer 2013. For questions, comments, or to submit thoughts and ideas for upcoming STARS publications, please email stars@aashe.org. View current publications.

WINTER 2012

The Winter 2012 SQR: Recap & A Look Ahead, reviews recent developments related to the evolving concept of global campus sustainability and introduces changes that can be expected for STARS in 2013.

Universidad de Monterrey (Mexico) is highlighted as the first STARS International Pilot participant to submit a STARS report and earn a rating.  

As STARS matures, more institutions are submitting multiple reports and using STARS as a tool for continuous improvement. Four institutions have been highlighted for recent advancements and initiatives identified in their most recent STARS reports.

Closing out the year, this edition looks at changes that can be expected for STARS in 2013, with descriptions of new credits proposed for the launch of STARS 2.0 slated for release in 2013. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

FALL 2012

The Fall 2012 SQR: The Role of Institutional Diversity, explores how the diversity of STARS institutions has changed over time and how participation in STARS according to institution type compares to U.S. demographics. Findings in this review suggest that the institutional characteristics that make higher education institutions distinct also play a role in how campuses are advancing sustainability. Particularly compelling is how NCAA conference rivalry is furthering sustainability on campuses. With 6 institutions highlighted, this issue covers data from reports submitted through September 1, 2012.  

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Summer 2012

The Summer 2012 SQR: Innovations in Campus Sustainability,  explores the critical linkages between education, innovation, and sustainability.  This issue highlights new and ground-breaking practices within the Innovation (IN) category of STARS, focusing on the unique solutions within higher education that positively impact current and future generations.   With 11 institutions highlighted, this issue covers data from reports submitted through June 1, 2012.  

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Spring 2012

The Spring 2012 SQR: Framing Campus Sustainability, features stories that frame the evolving concept of sustainability in higher education.  Included in this issue are a snapshot of ratings-to-date, a focus on credits within the Operations (OP) category, and insights into how institutions are defining and interpreting the evolving concepts of sustainability.  Highlighting AASHE's direction of serving as a thought leader to advance sustainability, this issue covers data from reports submitted through March 1, 2012.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Spring 2011

The Association for the Advancement of Sustainability in Higher Education (AASHE) released its first annual "STARS: A Year in Review" on April 14, 2011. This report details the sustainability efforts found in the inaugural submissions to the Sustainability Tracking, Assessment, Rating & System (STARS), such as sustainability research opportunities, sustainable dining efforts, and campus-wide social justice initiatives.

Thirty-seven institutions submitted their STARS Reports in time for inclusion in the review. There are more than 200 additional institutions participating in STARS that will be submitting reports for a rating in the coming year.

“The STARS annual review provides a wealth of information about the state of campus sustainability,” said AASHE Executive Director Paul Rowland. “Case studies, best practices, exemplary programs, and interesting facts can all be found in the document. We hope that it will inspire continued growth of sustainability efforts in higher education.”

In addition to a broad range of information provided in the institutional reports submitted by STARS Participants, “STARS: A Year in Review” captures the insights and knowledge gained by those institutions during the reporting process. Of particular note are the following findings:

 

 

  • Of the first 37 submissions, which came from a variety of institution types, eight earned a Gold Rating, 19 earned Silver, nine earned Bronze, and one earned a Reporter Rating.
  • Seven of the eight STARS Gold institutions scored more than 17 of the 18 possible points in the Co-Curricular Education subcategory, which focuses on non-academic programming that supports sustainability learning.
  • On average, 58% of the applicable points in the water subcategory were earned by STARS Participants.
  • Ten institutions earned 100% of the points available in both the Diversity and Affordability subcategory and the Coordination and Planning subcategory, which together include a total of 13 sustainability indicators.
  • A total of 71 sustainability innovations were reported (nearly two per institution)

The STARS Program provides ongoing opportunities for institutions to participate.  Institutions that are ready to register may do so online.  More information about the STARS program can be obtained by browsing the website, reviewing the STARS Overview presentation (pdf) or contacting us at stars@aashe.org.

fields.title: Program Overview
fields.content:
What is STARS?
What are the goals of STARS?
What are the benefits of participating in STARS?
How is STARS organized?

What is STARS?
STARS is an innovative, voluntary self-reporting framework for colleges and universities to gauge progress toward sustainability and be recognized for sustainability leadership.

What are the goals of STARS?
 STARS is designed to:

  • Provide a guide for advancing sustainability in all sectors of higher education, from education and research to operations and administration.
  • Enable meaningful comparisons over time and across institutions by establishing a common standard of measurement for sustainability in higher education.
  • Create incentives for continual improvement toward sustainability.
  • Facilitate information sharing about higher education sustainability practices and performance.
  • Build a stronger, more diverse campus sustainability community and promote a comprehensive understanding of sustainability that includes its social, economic and environmental dimensions. 

What are the benefits of participating in STARS?
There are several benefits associated with being a STARS Participant. STARS will help schools set and meet sustainability goals and will foster information sharing about practices and performance among the campus sustainability community. All schools that participate in STARS will receive positive recognition. Schools that register now will be recognized as STARS Participants. Being able to claim a STARS rating can help an institution reap marketing and recruitment benefits of sustainability leadership.

How is STARS organized?
Institutions earn points in three main categories: Education & Research; Operations; and Planning, Administration & Engagement. Each of these categories includes subcategories such as Purchasing, Curriculum, Energy, and Human Resources. There is also an Innovation category to recognize pioneering practices that aren’t covered by other STARS credits.

See a list (pdf) of common STARS terms and definitions.
fields.teaser:
What is STARS?
What are the goals of STARS?
What are the benefits of participating in STARS?
How is STARS organized?

fields.title: Sharing Data Overview
fields.content:
Since March 2011, the Association for the Advancement of Sustainability in Higher Education (AASHE), The Princeton Review, Sierra magazine, and the Sustainable Endowments Institute has been collaborating on an effort to streamline the reporting process for institutions that choose to participate in various higher education sustainability assessments. The intent of this initiative is to streamline the reporting process and reduce the amount of time campus staff spend completing related surveys.

To address this issue, The Princeton Review, Sierra magazine, and the Sustainable Endowments Institute have worked with AASHE to establish the Campus Sustainability Data Collector as the source for information needed to complete their publications (The Princeton Review Green Rating, Sierra magazine’s Cool Schools issue, and the Sustainable Endowment Institute’s College Sustainability Report Card, respectively.  Please note, the Sustainable Endowments Institute has suspended the production of the College Sustainability Report Card and will no longer be seeking data for this publication). In addition, there are some data points, not included in STARS, which these organizations are also interested in, that AASHE has identified as supplemental data in the reporting process. This will allow institutions that want to participate in the various programs to complete the information needed by each organization and enable the organizations to collect this information without having to send out individual surveys to institutions.

How it Works

STARS Participants reporting under the most current version of the STARS Technical Manual will be able to share the information documented for each STARS credit in the STARS Reporting Tool with The Princeton Review and/or Sierra magazine if they choose to do so. Institutions that are not STARS Participants will also have an opportunity to streamline the reporting process for data requested by these organizations by using the Campus Sustainability Data Collector.  However, the process will be a bit different for institutions that are not participating in STARS.

Please note, the Sustainable Endowments Institute has suspended the production of the College Sustainability Report Card and will no longer be seeking data for this publication.

For STARS Participants

The Princeton Review and Sierra magazine are seeking data from specific STARS credits to be considered in their evaluation of institutional sustainability efforts for their publications.  In addition, Sierra magazine is seeking one supplemental data field (SD 10). Any information documented in the supplemental section does not impact a STARS rating and will not be posted publicly in an institution’s STARS Report. Completing these fields is optional but important if your institution would like to be considered for inclusion in Sierra magazine's Cool Schools issue. Please note, the Sustainable Endowments Institute has suspended the production of the College Sustainability Report Card and will no longer be seeking data for this publication.

To share data through the STARS Reporting Tool with either The Princeton Review or Sierra magazine, institutions will take a ‘snapshot’ of the data marked as ‘pursuing’ in the Reporting Tool.  Instructions for how to successfully take and share a snapshot of data are outlined in the “Share Data” tab of the “My Summary” page in the Reporting Tool.  Each institution has the ability to share its data with the organizations of their choosing. Though all STARS data submitted for a STARS Report is public, STARS Participants may share data with organizations outside of AASHE without submitting a STARS Report. Sharing your institution’s data through the ‘Share Data’ tab in the STARS Reporting Tool allows organizations to gain access to the data in a user-friendly manner that is easy to analyze. Please note, The Princeton Review and Sierra magazine each have a different target audience and therefore may not include data from all institutions in their various publications.

Institutions will need to be working in the most up-to-date version of the STARS Technical Manual in order to share data.  Institutions that wish to migrate their data to the latest version of STARS may do so by choosing the “Migrate” tab in the “My Summary” page of the STARS Reporting Tool.  Please note, migrating data may take some time so please be patient.  Also, once the migration is complete, each credit will be marked as “In Progress.” Only credits marked as “Pursing” will be captured in a snapshot of data to be shared with other organizations. Changing a credit from “In Progress” to “Pursuing” must be done manually by going through each credit. The reason that AASHE marks an institution's credits as "In Progress" when a migration is complete is because we don't feel comfortable deciding what an institution may or may not "Pursue" after the migration process.

For Institutions not participating in STARS

AASHE has created the Campus Sustainability Data Collector for institutions not currently participating in STARS. Institutions that register under the Campus Sustainability Data Collector are referred to as Survey Respondents. This basic tool allows any higher education institution the option to share campus sustainability data with The Princeton Review and/or Sierra Magazine. Please note, the Sustainable Endowments Institute has suspended the production of the College Sustainability Report Card and will no longer be seeking data for this publication. The Data Collector is modeled after the STARS Reporting Tool and is available at no cost. However, this option does not include any of the benefits of the STARS Reporting Tool or those associated with being a STARS Participant.

While the STARS Reporting Tool includes beneficial features like automated calculations, multiple user access, and data collection resources, the Campus Sustainability Data Collector is simply a place to upload and share sustainability data. This information is not available to the public and institutions that use the Data Collector will not receive any recognition other than submission to publications that they choose to share their data with.

Once your institution has registered for the Data Collector, it will access the tool from the “Reporting” link in the toolbar at the top of the STARS website. Uploading of data will take place in the “My Submission” section of the Data Collector.  Survey Respondents will be given the option to allow organizations outside of AASHE to have access to your data in the “Share Data” tab of the “My Summary” page in the Campus Sustainability Data Collector. Each institution has the ability to share their data with the organizations they choose by taking a ‘snapshot’ of the data marked as ‘pursuing’ in the Data Collector.  Instructions for how to successfully take and share a snapshot of data are outlined in the “Share Data” tab of the “My Summary” page in the Data Collector. Please note, The Princeton Review and Sierra magazine each have a different target audience and therefore may not include data from all institutions in their various publications.

Institutions will need to be working in the most up-to-date version of the STARS Technical Manual in order to share data.  Institutions that wish to migrate their data to the latest version of STARS may do so by choosing the “Migrate” tab in the “My Summary” page of the Campus Sustainability Data Collector.  Institutions that have a valid STARS rating but are not currently registered STARS Participants may migrate data from the STARS Reporting Tool to the Campus Sustainability Data Collector. This option is available at no cost. Please note, migrating data from the STARS Reporting Tool to the Campus Sustainability Data Collector may take some time, so please be patient.  Also, once the migration is complete, each credit will be marked as “In Progress.” Only credits marked as “Pursing” will be captured in a snapshot of data to be shared with other organizations. Changing a credit from “In Progress” to “Pursuing” must be done manually by going through each credit. The reason that AASHE marks an institution's credits as "In Progress" when a migration is complete is because we don't feel comfortable deciding what an institution may or may not "Pursue" after the migration process.

*Please note, regardless of whether your institution is a STARS Participant or a Campus Sustainability Data Collector Survey Respondent it MUST take a snapshot of its data and share this information to be considered for another organizations' publication. Instructions for taking and sharing snapshots of data are outlined in the "Share Data" tab of the "My Summary" section in the STARS Reporting Tool and Data Collector.

Registration

The following table outlines how to register for STARS as a STARS Participant or how to complete the registration process to become a Campus Sustainability Data Collector Survey Respondent. 

Step by Step

STARS Participant

Survey Respondent

1. Register

Go to stars.aashe.org and pay $900 for AASHE members or $1400 for non-members. Renewing institutions can register at a 50% discount

Go to stars.aashe.org and register for the Campus Sustainability Data Collector (no payment is required)

2. Data collection

Use the STARS Reporting Tool to post and track your data.

Use the Campus Sustainability Data Collector to input data

3. Share your data

Select organizations that you want to share your data with

Select organizations that you want to share your data with

4. Submit

 Submit to receive a STARS Rating and have your data publicly posted Submit data (does not go public)

Timeline

In addition to submitting for a STARS rating once a year, STARS Participants will also be able to save an unlimited number of snapshots of their data to share with The Princeton Review and/or Sierra magazine. Please note, the Sustainable Endowments Institute has suspended the production of the College Sustainability Report Card and will no longer be seeking data for this publication.

Survey Respondents may submit data through the Campus Sustainability Data Collector for the Princeton Review and/or Sierra magazine to access. However, if institutions want to update their data throughout the year, they will need to resubmit their entire submission, they will not have access to the data previously submitted. Accessing saved data, once it has been submitted to these rating organizations, is a benefit of participating in STARS.

The dates listed below refer to the time frame that each organization will be seeking information from STARS Participants and Survey Respondents in order to include this information in their respective publications.

The Princeton Review - Feb. 8, 2013 (approximately)
Sierra magazine - Jun. 1, 2012

Questions

For questions regarding the individual organizations collaborating on the Campus Sustainability Data Collector, please use the following contact information:

  • STARS – stars@aashe.org
  • The Princeton Review – surveysupport@review.com
  • Sierra magazine – cool.schools@sierraclub.org
fields.teaser:
Since March 2011, the Association for the Advancement of Sustainability in Higher Education (AASHE), The Princeton Review, Sierra magazine, and the Sustainable Endowments Institute has been collaborating on an effort to streamline the reporting process for institutions that choose to participate in various higher education sustainability assessments. The intent of this initiative is to reduce and streamline the amount of time campus staff spend tracking sustainability data and completing related surveys.

To address this issue, The Princeton Review, Sierra magazine, and the Sustainable Endowments Institute have worked with AASHE to establish the Campus Sustainability Data Collector as the source for information needed to complete their publications (The Princeton Review Green Rating, Sierra magazine’s Cool Schools issue, and the Sustainable Endowment Institute’s College Sustainability Report Card, respectively.  Please note, the Sustainable Endowments Institute has suspended the production of the College Sustainability Report Card and will no longer be seeking data for this publication). In addition, there are some data points, not included in STARS, which these organizations are also interested in, that AASHE has identified as supplemental data in the reporting process. This will allow institutions that want to participate in the various programs to complete the information needed by each organization and enable the organizations to collect this information without having to send out individual surveys to institutions.

fields.title: Steering Committee
fields.content:
The STARS Steering Committee is comprised of campus representatives, members of the AASHE Board of Directors, and AASHE Staff.  STARS Steering Committee members advise on program policy, finances, and strategic positioning, in addition to reviewing and approving updates and revisions to the technical content of STARS, including each new version.  View the STARS Governance Structure (pdf).

Steering Committee Members

Campus Representatives

Julian Dautremont-Smith - Chief Sustainability Officer, Alfred State College

Jeremy Friedman -Manager, Sustainability Initiatives, New York University

Elaine Hanson - Director, Office for Sustainability, Sheridan College

Preston Jacobsen - Sustainability Analyst, Haywood Community College

Nurit Katz - Chief Sustainability Officer, University of California, Los Angeles

H. Scott Matthews - Faculty and Research Director, Carnegie Mellon University

Chris O'Brien - Director of Sustainability, American University

Stephenie Presseller - Sustainability Manager, Moraine Valley Community College

Cindy Shea - Director, Sustainability Office, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

AASHE Board Members 

William Brown - Director of Sustainability,  Indiana University

Jon Jensen - Director of Environmental Studies, Luther College

Dave Newport - Director, Environmental Center, University of Colorado at Boulder

AASHE Staff

Meghan Fay Zahniser - Director of Programs, AASHE

Paul Rowland - Executive Director, AASHE

View the Steering Committee Members' bios (pdf).

Roles and Responsibilities

STARS Steering Committee Members:

  • Advise on STARS policy, finances, and strategic positioning in response to proposals from staff and other Committee Members and make recommendations to the AASHE Board of Directors and STARS staff as necessary. For example, the Steering Committee may be asked to provide feedback on topics such as educational offerings, revenue opportunities, partnerships or other activities related to the success of the program.
  • Review and approve updates and revisions to the technical content of STARS, including each new version.
  • Determine the appropriate course of action when a submission is contested and the issue cannot be resolved by staff.

The committee generally meets once a month by conference call and in-person as needed. Members are expected to attend calls and contribute sufficient time to address the continued development and strategic positioning of STARS. Members receive no remuneration for their services.

fields.title: Technical Manual
fields.content:
STARS 2.0 is the current version of STARS.  The STARS 2.0 Technical Manual (pdf) is the go-to guide for the STARS credits and is organized into four main categories (Academics, Engagement, Operations, and Planning & Administration), which are broken down into sub-categories where the individual STARS credits are located.

Note: This is the most current version of the STARS Technical Manual and is different from the pre-launch version, which was shared with the public in August 2013, and includes administrative updates (pdf).  

 

 

 

 

 

 

Credit Outline

Each STARS credit in the Technical Manual includes the following details:

  • Credit Rationale–provides background on the importance of the credit in the context of sustainability.
  • Criteria–describes how an institution earns points for the credit.
  • Applicability–indicates which institutions’ STARS scores will be affected by their responses to the credit. Some credits do not apply to some types of institutions. For example, credits involving residence halls do not apply to institutions that do not have residence halls.
  • Scoring–explains how points are allocated for the credit.
  • Reporting Fields–lists the fields that appear within the Reporting Tool for each credit. Some fields are required while others are listed as optional if the institution wishes to provide additional information.
  • Timeframe–describes the time period from which data should be drawn. For some credits, particularly those that are based on the presence of a policy or program, institutions should report on current practices (i.e. status at the time of reporting). Other credits, particularly those based on quantitative performance, require historical performance data, typically drawn from a one-year period.
  • Sampling and Data Standards–provides guidelines on when institutions may use a representative sample to measure performance and when samples are prohibited.

The STARS 2.0 Credit Checklist (pdf) provides a quick snapshot of the credits included in STARS 2.0. Data collected for each STARS credit is documented in the STARS Reporting Tool, which is only available to current STARS Participants. Current STARS Participants registered under a previous version of STARS may migrate data to the current version. View the STARS 2.0 Summary of Changes | Administrative Update One (pdf) for a list of updates between STARS 1.2 and STARS 2.0.  

Credit Development

STARS credits were initially developed in large part by reviewing campus sustainability assessments, sustainability reports from businesses, and other sustainability rating and ranking systems. The current version of STARS incorporates feedback and suggestions from hundreds of diverse stakeholders and experts. For more information see previous versions of the STARS Technical Manual. 

Credits vary in the number of points they are worth. Points were allocated by a panel of STARS Steering Committee members and AASHE staff using the following considerations:

  1. To what extent does achievement of the credit ensure that people (students, employees and/or local community members) acquire the knowledge, skills, and dispositions to meet sustainability challenges?
  2. To what extent does achievement of the credit contribute to:

a. human and ecological health and mitigate negative environmental impacts?

b. secure livelihoods, a sustainable economy and other positive financial impacts?

c. social justice, equity, diversity, cooperation, democracy and other positive social impacts?

3. To what extent are the positive impacts associated with achievement of the credit not captured in other STARS credits?

Impact vs. Difficulty

As these questions indicate, the focus in allocating points was on the impact, not the difficulty, of earning the credit. Some sustainability initiatives may be very difficult to implement but yield negligible impacts. Conversely, some generally easier projects have significant impacts. Assigning points based on the difficulty of earning a credit would create a perverse incentive for institutions to focus on the difficult projects or initiatives, which may not have the most meaningful impact. 

Given the diversity of higher education institutions, each STARS credit should be appropriate for most institution types. In order to accommodate this diversity, some STARS credits do not include detailed specifications but are instead flexible or open. In other cases, credits include an applicability criterion, so that the credits only apply to certain types of institutions. By following this approach, institutions are not penalized when they do not earn credits that they could not possibly earn due to their circumstances. 

Additionally, STARS is designed to incorporate the full spectrum of sustainability achievement, and upper levels of achievement represent highly ambitious, long-term goals. Therefore there are some credits for which few, if any, institutions will achieve full points currently. 

Lastly, to help ensure that the system works as intended, AASHE strived to ensure that each credit was objective, measurable, and actionable.

fields.title: Why Participate?
fields.content:
There are many benefits associated with becoming a STARS Participant. According to STARS Participants, here are the top ten reasons to register: 

1) Earn Recognition for Sustainability Efforts on Your Campus
2) Save Time and Money in Developing a Sustainability Report or Plan
3) Streamline Reporting on Your Campus by Using Common Metrics
4) Use STARS as a Guide to Set Goals and Generate New Ideas
5) STARS Requires Collaborate Across Campus for Data Collection
6) Adopt STARS as a Teaching and Learning Tool
7) Ability to Shape the STARS System by Providing Feedback
8) Access STARS Resources in the 'My Resources' Section of the STARS Reporting Tool
9) Benchmark Your STARS Report with Peers
10) Easily Communicate Your Achievements by Sharing Your STARS Report

Benefits

Benefits of becoming a STARS Participant include, but are not limited to:

  • Access to the online STARS Reporting Tool, which includes:

         - Data synchronization with other specific rating and ranking organizations
         - Automated point calculation for each STARS credit
         - PDF Exports of Submission Data
         - Ability to share data with other organizations outside of AASHE
         - Continuous access to update data
         - Option to give multiple users access to the STARS Report
         - Data tracking resources
         - STARS seal logo
         - Email templates
         - Template press release
         - Promotional tools

  • Earn a STARS rating and be recognized as a STARS rated institution
  • Publicly posted STARS Report on the STARS website
  • Full access to STARS Data Displays
  • Opportunities to influence STARS technical development
  • Inclusion in STARS Quarterly Review
  • Free admission to STARS webinars
  • And more!

View a printable version of the STARS Participant benefits (pdf).

fields.title: STARS History and System Development
fields.content:
How was STARS developed?
Why does STARS include “social” indicators? Isn’t sustainability mostly about the environment?
What are the main differences between the credits in the STARS Pilot and STARS 1.0?
How will the system be updated?
When will the system be updated?

How was STARS developed?
In 2006 the Higher Education Associations' Sustainability Consortium (HEASC), an informal network of higher education associations with a commitment to sustainability, issued a call for a campus sustainability rating system (pdf). Since then, AASHE has worked collaboratively with other non-profits and higher education associations on the development of STARS. A Steering Committee, Strategic Advisory Committee, and a Technical Advisory Committee weighed in on the system and nearly 70 institutions participated in a year-long pilot program.

Why does STARS include “social” indicators? Isn’t sustainability mostly about the environment?
The most commonly used definition of sustainability–meeting the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs–is from Our Common Future: The Report of the World Commission on Environment and Development, commonly known as the Brundtland Commission report. The interconnectedness and interdependence of the social, environmental, and economic dimensions of sustainability are included throughout Our Common Future. The Brundtland Commission writes, “our inability to promote the common interest in sustainable development is often a product of the relative neglect of economic and social justice.” The report continues, “[a] world in which poverty and inequity are endemic will always be prone to ecological and other crises. Sustainable development requires meeting the basic needs of all and extending to all the opportunity to satisfy their aspirations for a better life.” And, "[e]ven the narrow notion of physical sustainability implies a concern for social equity between generations, a concern that must logically be extended to equity within each generation."

Many popular uses of and references to sustainability also emphasize the concept’s economic, environmental, and social dimensions. For example, businesses talk about the triple bottom line: people, planet, and profits (or, alternately, human capital, natural capital, and financial capital). Likewise, sustainability educators commonly refer to the Three Es of sustainability: economy, ecology, and equity. Similarly, popular representations of sustainability underscore the concept’s three dimensions. Sustainability experts often use a three-legged stool as a symbol for sustainability. The social, economic, and environmental components of sustainability each represent one of the stool’s legs. If one of the legs is missing, the stool cannot balance or function. Another common illustration of sustainability is a diagram depicting three overlapping circles, representing environmental needs, economic needs and social needs. The area where the circles overlap and all three needs are met is the area of sustainability.

STARS represents an attempt to translate this broad and inclusive view of sustainability to measurable objectives at the campus level. Thus, it includes credits related to an institution’s environmental, social, and economic performance.

What are the main differences between the STARS Pilot and STARS 1.0?
First, some credits–particularly those for which gathering data proved especially difficult or impossible–have been eliminated. In addition, STARS 1.0 does not include prerequisites.

Second, additional definitions and guidelines have been added to many credits in an effort to make the credit criteria clearer.

Third, for the first time, AASHE has gone through a deliberate credit weighting or point allocation exercise. In other words, the point value assigned to each credit has been evaluated relative to other credits such that the credits that have the greatest impact on an institutions’ sustainability performance are worth the most points.

Fourth, many credits have been restructured such that partial points are available. This approach better recognizes incremental change and creates a stronger incentive for continued progress toward sustainability.

How will the system be updated?
AASHE will continue to work with STARS participants and the campus sustainability community to improve the system. Comments or feedback on STARS may be sent to the STARS staff at any time (stars@aashe.org). Before a new version (e.g., STARS 2.0) is released, AASHE will hold a public comment period to allow stakeholders an opportunity to comment on proposed changes. View details about the development process and timeline in the Technical Development Policy (pdf).

When will the system be updated?
Major changes to the system will likely occur every two or three years. In the mean time, AASHE may make small changes and clarifying edits to the STARS Technical Manual to respond to participants’ needs.  View details about the development process and timeline (pdf).

How was STARS developed?
Why does STARS include “social” indicators? Isn’t sustainability mostly about the environment?
What are the main differences between the credits in the STARS Pilot and STARS 1.0?
How will the system be updated?
When will the system be updated?

fields.title: Participation
fields.content:
Who can participate in STARS?
Can an entire university system register?
How often can an institution submit for a STARS Rating?
How much does it cost to participate?
Why must AASHE member campuses pay an additional fee to participate in STARS?
How long do institutions have to complete STARS?
Will campuses be able to see the STARS criteria before signing up to be a Participant?
How do I register to become a STARS Participant?
What is the difference between a “Charter Participant” and a regular “Participant”?
Can an institution participate in STARS without being scored?

Who can participate in STARS?
Any college or university located in the U.S. or Canada may participate. 

STARS provides a framework for institutions taking first steps toward sustainability as well as established sustainability leaders. An institution is defined by having a separate and distinct administration (e.g. president or chancellor). For an institution which may be a part of a larger system, it must have an administration that is separate and distinct from others in the system of which it is a part.

If an institution or entity does not meet these requirements, but you believe that you have a compelling case for the participation of that institution or entity in STARS, please complete the Eligibility Inquiry Form. This information will be evaluated by the STARS staff, who will decide if the institution or entity is eligible to participate in STARS.

Can an entire university system register?
Yes, university systems or community college districts may register and report as one entity. However, AASHE expects that most participants will be individual institutions.

How often can an institution submit for a STARS Rating?
An institution that registers for STARS gains 12-months of continual access to the STARS Reporting Tool and may submit for a STARS rating once during this 12-month period.  A STARS rating is valid for three years.  After three years, institutions will need to submit a subsequent STARS Report to claim a valid rating. Institutions may submit for a subsequent rating by renewing membership at any time, provided that all data accuracy mechanisms are followed.  

How much will it cost to participate?
STARS registration fees:
AASHE Member.......................................$900
Non-Member...........................................$1,400

Discount for renewing STARS Participants:
AASHE Member …………………......................$450
Non-Member ……………….……......................$700

The STARS fee is due at the time of your institution's registration for STARS. Once your institution has paid the STARS registration fee, data collection and documentation in the STARS Reporting Tool may begin. Access to the Reporting Tool will continue for 12 months. No additional fees are required to complete your submission. 

AASHE encourages institutions to participate in STARS on an annual basis. Any institution that registers for STARS within 90 days of its subscription expiration date will be eligible for the 50% discount (i.e. $450 for AASHE members and $700 for non-members).

For more information about AASHE Membership, please visit the AASHE website.

Why must AASHE member campuses pay an additional fee to participate in STARS?
STARS is a program of AASHE that is open to all institutions. AASHE member institutions receive a discount. AASHE instituted a fee for STARS to pay for the costs of continued development and maintenance of the rating system, including the online Reporting Tool (available only to STARS participants) and new resources for participants. AASHE income and expenditure figures, including those related to STARS, are posted in the annual budget, which can be downloaded from our governance page.

How long do institutions have to complete STARS?
STARS Participants receive 12-months of continuous access to the STARS Reporting Tool and are encouraged to submit their STARS Report during this time frame. Once a STARS Participant submits its STARS Report and earns a STARS rating, this rating is valid for three years.  However, STARS Participants are encouraged to participate in STARS on an annual basis and have the opportunity to do so, at a discounted rate, so they can continue tracking their STARS data.

Will campuses be able to see the STARS criteria before signing up to be a Participant?
Yes, the STARS Technical Manual, which outlines all of the details of the STARS credits, is publicly available.

How do I register to become a STARS Participant?
You can register online and payments can be made either online or by check (mailed to AASHE’s office). At registration, the registrant will be asked for the name and contact information for your primary STARS Liaison as well as your Executive Contact (president, vice president, provost, chancellor, etc.) who will be included on an email confirming your institution’s STARS registration.

What is the difference between a “Charter Participant” and a regular “Participant”?
A STARS Charter Participant is an institution that registered to use STARS between September 20, 2009, and August 20, 2010. Charter participants will be recognized in STARS publicity and on the STARS website. Institutions that register for STARS after August 20, 2010, will be referred to as STARS “Participants"

Can an institution participate in STARS without being scored?
An institution that wishes to participate in STARS but does not want their scores to be public, may earn recognition through the STARS Reporter rating. These institutions receive the same benefits as institutions that pursue any other STARS rating, including positive recognition for participation and the ability to share data publicly. After seeing their final score, all participants are able to choose STARS Reporter status before completing their final submission and making it public.

fields.title: Reporting and Information Sharing
fields.content:
How do I get started with STARS after I successfully register as a STARS Participant?
What does it mean to migrate data and how does the migration function work?
What is the difference between ‘Version Migration’ and ‘Data Migration'?
How do I share my STARS data with Sierra magazine and The Princeton Review to be considered for their publications?
How can institutions demonstrate they have earned a credit?
What timeframe should I use when reporting data for STARS?
What should the President's Letter include and where do I upload it in the STARS Reporting Tool?
Will the STARS data be made public?
What if institutions don't want to disclose certain information or make it publicly available (investment information, for example) or if an institution just wants to post one of the sections?
If I believe there is erroneous data in an institution's STARS Report, how do I report it?
How do I correct information in my institution's STARS Report after the information has been made public?
Can I use the STARS logo?
Our institution is currently registered for STARS 1.0 or STARS 1.1 and we noticed that a new version of STARS (1.2) has been launched. How are we affected by the release of STARS 1.2?
Are there any special considerations for institutions submitting subsequent reports?

How do I get started with STARS after I successfully register as a STARS Participant?
Visit the "Getting Started" section of the STARS "Help" webpage for steps outlining the details of the STARS process from once your institution registers for STARS to after it submits a STARS Report and earns a rating. 

What does it mean to migrate data and how does the migration function work?
Institutions working in the STARS Reporting Tool will have the opportunity to migrate data.  “Version Migrations” allow an institution to migrate between different versions of the STARS Technical Manual.  “Data Migrations” allow STARS Participants to migrate previously saved data sets into the STARS Reporting Tool.

STARS Participants seeking to migrate data will use the migration function in the STARS Reporting Tool by navigating to the 'My Summary' page and choosing the 'Migrate' tab.  Please note that it may take a few minutes for migration to complete, during which time the 'My Submission' section of the Reporting Tool will be locked. Migrating data will replace any previously saved data and all credits are marked as “In Progress” after migration is complete.  Changes to credit status must be done manually.

What is the difference between ‘Version Migration’ and ‘Data Migration'?
'Version Migrations' allow an institution to migrate between different versions of the STARS Technical Manual.  For example, an institution may have registered under a version of STARS, such as 1.1, but during the institution's subscription to the STARS Reporting Tool another version of STARS was launched, such as 1.2.  Completing a 'Version Migration' will allow the institution to update credits that are outlined in the 'My Submission' section of the STARS Reporting Tool so that this information reflects the most current version of the STARS credits. Data saved in the STARS Reporting Tool prior to the migration will be visible in the Reporting Tool once the migration is complete. 

“Data Migrations” allow STARS Participants to migrate previously saved data sets into the STARS Reporting Tool. For example, institutions may choose to pull data from a previously submitted STARS Report, or saved snapshot, into the STARS Reporting Tool. Completing a 'Data Migration' will allow the institution to work off of the specific data set that is moved into the STARS Reporting Tool instead of documenting data from scratch. Migrating data will replace any previously saved data.

STARS Participants seeking to migrate data will use the migration function in the STARS Reporting Tool by navigating to the 'My Summary' page and choosing the 'Migrate' tab.  Please note that it may take a few minutes for a migration to complete, during which time the 'My Submission' section of the Reporting Tool will be locked. Migrating data will replace any previously saved data and all credits are marked as “In Progress” after migration is complete.  Changes to credit status must be done manually.

How do I share my STARS data with Sierra magazine and The Princeton Review to be considered for their publications?
STARS Participants seeking to share data with other organizations must take a snapshot of the data documented in the STARS Reporting Tool and share this information. Instructions for taking and sharing snapshots of data are outlined in the "Share Data" tab of the "My Summary" section in the STARS Reporting Tool.

 How can institutions demonstrate that they earn a credit?
There are specific reporting fields that institutions complete to demonstrate that they earn STARS credits. These reporting fields are outlined in the STARS Technical Manual. All information is submitted to AASHE through an online Reporting Tool.

What timeframe should I use when reporting data for STARS?
Some credits are based on current practices and others are based on historical performance. The STARS Technical Manual includes guidance on what timeframe to use for each credit. For credits that are based on historical data, schools can choose the timeframe for each credit separately; there is no requirement that an institution use the same time period to gather data for all credits. The key requirement for credits that use annual data is that the data are drawn from a consecutive 12-month period.

What should the President's Letter include and where do I upload it in the STARS Reporting Tool?
Each submittal for a STARS rating must be accompanied by a letter from the institution's president, chancellor, or highest ranking executive that affirms the accuracy of the institution's STARS Submission. In addition, the president or chancellor's letter serves as an introduction or cover letter for the submission. As such, the letter may also include a description of the institution's commitment to sustainability, background about the institution, key achievements or highlights from the STARS submission, and goals for future submissions. Sign-off from the institution's president or chancellor is an important strategy for promoting accuracy within the STARS self-assessment framework.

When an institution chooses the button to "Submit for Rating" in the STARS Reporting Tool, the institution will be prompted to upload a PDF version of the letter from the president or chancellor in the second step of the submission process. Please allow for adequate time to secure the letter before submitting for a rating. 

Will the STARS data be made public?
Once data documentation in the STARS Reporting Tool is complete, and the data are submitted to AASHE, the institution will earn the STARS rating it achieved and its STARS Report will become public on the STARS website. All data submitted in the institutions STARS Report will be public except for the "Internal Notes" section of each credit. During the pilot period, all information was kept confidential. Review the STARS Pilot Project Results (pdf) for outcomes from the pilot.

What if institutions don't want to disclose certain information or make it publicly available (investment information, for example) or if an institution just wants to post one of the sections?
Participation in STARS is voluntary and institutions may choose to skip any credits or categories. However, since public reporting is important to the credibility of STARS, institutions will not earn points for credits if they do not provide the required information.

If I believe there is erroneous data in an institution's STARS Report, how do I report it?
Individuals with questions about a STARS report have the option to fill out a STARS Submission Accuracy Inquiry Form. Questioners have the option to remain anonymous to the institution receiving the inquiry.  A representative of the STARS Team will evaluate incoming accuracy inquiries and, assuming the questioner has provided sufficient information to merit further review, the STARS representative will work with the relevant STARS Liaison to respond to the question and communicate back with the questioner. For more information, please review the complete Submission Review Policy approved by the STARS Steering Committee (policy currently under review).

How do I correct information in my institution's STARS Report after the information has been made public?
If an institution realizes it has made a mistake when documenting information in the STARS Reporting Tool after the information has been submitted for a STARS rating and is public on the STARS website, an individual assigned to the Administrator role within the Reporting Tool may correct this information by submitting a Data Corrections Request through the institution’s STARS Report. The STARS Administrator will simply view the credit to be updated in the institution’s STARS Report on the STARS website and click on the pencil icon next to that credit. The icon will lead the STARS Administrator to the Data Corrections Request Form.  Note that the Data Corrections Request form must be accessed through the institution's public report, not through the Reporting Tool.  

Upon submitting this form, the STARS team will review the form to ensure the submitted information reflects a legitimate correction (as opposed to, for example, an update). Corrections will then be made to the institution’s STARS Report. The corrected information in the institution’s STARS Report will include a date stamp and note that explains the reason for the change and will be publicly available. The details of this process are explained in the Policy for Correcting Mistakes in the Reporting Tool.

The process for making corrections to an institution’s STARS Report will be the same even if the change results in a new rating level. An institution may make corrections to its STARS Report with no charge up to a year after the STARS submission is received by AASHE. After that time, any institution-requested corrections require a processing fee of $150 per correction.  If corrections are in response to a data accuracy inquiry originating from an external party or from an AASHE staff member, no processing fee shall be required.

Can I use the STARS logo?
If you are interested in using the STARS logo, please email stars@aashe.org and explain why you're hoping to use the STARS logo and in what capacity. 

Our institution is currently registered for STARS 1.0 or STARS 1.1 and we noticed that a new version of STARS (1.2) has been launched. How are we affected by the release of STARS 1.2?
Institutions that have been using STARS 1.0 or STARS 1.1 may either continue reporting under this version of STARS or have the option to migrate their data into STARS 1.2. A button, which will actualize the migration, will be available in the Reporting Tool within the box at the top of the "My Summary" section. Institutions should note that not all of the reporting fields in STARS 1.0 and STARS 1.1 are the same as the reporting fields in STARS 1.2. This means that if an institution chooses to migrate its data from STARS 1.0 or STARS 1.1 into STARS 1.2, credits that were complete in the 1.0 or 1.1 version may require additional reporting to fulfill the requirements in the 1.2 version.

Are there any special considerations for institutions submitting subsequent reports?
Institutions submitting a subsequent report should be mindful of those areas within STARS that must be updated each time an institution submits for a new rating:

  • Time-frame - STARS reports should include an institution's most recent data available.  Although migrating data from previous reports makes submitting a subsequent report more efficient, institutions should review each field and update information based on the most recent data available.
  • Innovation credits - A criterion of the Innovation category in STARS states that "an institution can only claim a particular activity as an innovation credit once."  When re-submitting for a STARS rating, a previously-submitted innovation credit cannot be re-submitted.
  • President's letter - A letter from an institution's president, chancellor, or highest ranking CEO affirming the accuracy of a STARS report is required for each STARS submission.  Subsequent reports must include new letters of affirmation.

 

Institutions submitting a subsequent report should be mindful of those areas within a STARS report that must be updated each time an institution submits for a new rating: 

·         Timeframe – STARS reports should include an institution’s most recent data available.  Although migrating data from previous reports makes submitting a subsequent report more efficient, institutions should review each field and update information based on the most recent data available. 

·         President’s letter – A letter from an institution’s president, chancellor, or highest ranking CEO affirming the accuracy of a STARS report is required for each STARS submission.  Subsequent reports must include new letters of affirmation from the highest ranking CEO.

Innovation credits – A criterion for the Innovation category in STARS states that “An institution can only claim a particular activity as an innovation credit once. When re-submitting for a STARS rating, an innovation credit that the institution submitted previously cannot be re-submitted.”

fields.title: Ratings and Credits
fields.content:
What are the STARS rating levels?
What does earning a STARS rating mean?
How long is a STARS rating valid?
What will campuses get for earning a STARS rating?
How often can an institution submit for a STARS rating?
Is third-party verification required?
How will the public know that the information reported from institutions is true?
If I believe there is erroneous data in an institution's STARS Report, how do I report it?
How is innovation encouraged or rewarded?
Will STARS address the idea of getting campuses to take the "next step”?

What are the STARS rating levels?
STARS Bronze - minimum score required: 25
STARS Silver - minimum score required: 45
STARS Gold - minimum score required: 65
STARS Platinum - minimum score required: 85
STARS Reporter - no scores are made public

An institution that wishes to participate in STARS but does not want to publish their score may participate as a STARS Reporter. These institutions receive the same benefits as institutions that pursue a STARS rating, including positive recognition for participation and the ability to share data publicly. After seeing their final score, all participants are able to choose STARS Reporter status before completing their final submission and making it public.

What does earning a STARS rating mean?
Each STARS rating is an indication of sustainability leadership.  The STARS rating is earned by institutions that have registered for STARS and have gone through a comprehensive process of collecting and publicly reporting information related to their sustainability performance. STARS is a self-assessment and therefore AASHE does not certify or award ratings.  STARS ratings are achieved by institutions that have successfully completed a STARS submission and have earned the score that corresponds to a particular STARS rating level.

How long is a STARS rating valid?
A STARS rating is good for three years, however an institution may submit for a new STARS rating as often as once per year. An additional registration fee is required each time an institution resubmits for a rating.

What will campuses get for earning a STARS rating?
Campuses will be able to use a STARS logo with their rating level on their website and print materials. (Terms of use for this logo will be distributed when the institution receives the rating).

How often can an institution submit for a STARS rating?
An institution that registers for STARS gains 12-months of continual access to the STARS Reporting Tool. An institution may submit for a new STARS rating as often as once during this 12-month period. A STARS Rating is valid for three years.  After three years, an institution will need to resubmit a STARS Report to claim a valid rating.

Is third-party verification required?
At this time, third-party verification is not required nor does AASHE provide incentives for third-party verification.

How will the public know that the information reported from institutions is true?
STARS has built-in provisions to help ensure that information campuses submit is accurate.

  • First, for each credit, a point person from the institution will provide a statement that the information submitted is accurate.
  • Second, the institution’s president or chancellor must write a letter stating that all the information submitted is true.
  • Third, all information that the institution submits will be made publicly available through the STARS website.

If I believe there is erroneous data in an institution's STARS Report, how do I report it?
Individuals with questions about one or more fields in a STARS report may fill out a  STARS Submission Accuracy Inquiry Form. A STARS staff member will evaluate the data accuracy inquiry and will follow-up as appropriate with the institution in question.  Individuals have the option to remain anonymous to the institution receiving the inquiry.  For more information, please review the complete Submission Review Policy approved by the STARS Steering Committee (policy currently under review).

How is innovation encouraged or rewarded?
Like the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) green building rating system, STARS allocates points that reward innovative solutions to sustainability challenges. See the most current version of STARS for details associated with Innovation Credits.

Will STARS address the idea of getting campuses to take the "next step”?
STARS can be a starting point for institutions that are just beginning to address sustainability or it can be used as a vehicle for showcasing a leading institution’s innovative sustainability strategies. Since STARS includes ambitious, long-term sustainability achievements, all campuses will find something to strive for within the system.

fields.title: Relationship to Other Systems
fields.content:
What is the difference between STARS and other campus sustainability assessment systems?
Is AASHE working with the other systems so campuses don't have to complete so many surveys?
How do STARS and the American College and University Presidents’ Climate Commitment (ACUPCC) complement each other?

What is the difference between STARS and other campus sustainability assessment systems?

There are several key features that distinguish STARS from other campus sustainability rating systems, including the following:

  • Open development process–STARS is the result of a collaborative development process that involved hundreds of individuals and multiple public comment periods. Moving forward, AASHE will continue to engage stakeholders in higher education and sustainability, as well as the general public, to seek feedback on the system and ideas for improvements.
  • Fully transparent methodology–The criteria that determine a STARS rating are transparent and accessible to anyone. This means you can see exactly how each participating institution received its score and what your institution needs to do to improve its score.
  • High-quality data–The STARS Technical Manual provides detailed information about each credit to help ensure data comparability. Further, the STARS Reporting Tool incorporates controls that limit the possibility of user error. Moreover, STARS publishes submissions online and requires a “responsible party” to be associated with every credit. By contrast, other rating systems gather much of their data through surveys that provide limited supporting information and require little to no supporting documentation.
  • Comprehensive approach–STARS awards points for a broader variety of sustainability activity than other rating systems. Also, consistent with the original and long-standing meaning of sustainability, STARS includes credits related to an institution’s social performance, while other systems tend to focus exclusively or primarily on environmental performance.
  • Absolute scale–STARS ratings are based on an absolute scale of progress toward sustainability and are not relative to the performance of other institutions. There are a couple of benefits to this approach. First, the scale stays relatively constant over time, thereby providing greater predictability in scoring over time and avoiding the problems associated with “moving targets.” Second, the use of an absolute scale better encourages both cooperation among schools and continuous improvement toward sustainability since it keeps the focus on the end goal of sustainability rather than just on being better than other schools.
  • Community governance–STARS is the only campus sustainability rating system that is largely governed by members of the campus sustainability community. Additionally, it is the only system with the support and involvement of a variety of higher education associations.
  • Intended for institutions of all types–STARS is intended for all types of higher education institutions, from community colleges to research universities. Other rating systems were designed for specific types of institutions and often exclude other types.
  • Only positive ratings–STARS provides only positive recognition; there are no bad grades.

Overall, while we respect the role other systems have played in raising the visibility of campus sustainability, we believe that STARS provides a substantially more meaningful assessment of an institution’s sustainability performance than other systems available today.

Is AASHE working with the other systems so campuses don't have to complete so many surveys?
Yes. Since March 2011, the Association for the Advancement of Sustainability in Higher Education (AASHE), The Princeton Review, Sierra magazine, and the Sustainable Endowments Institute has been collaborating on an effort to streamline the reporting process for institutions that choose to participate in various higher education sustainability assessments. The intent of this initiative is to streamline the reporting process and reduce the amount of time campus staff spend completing related surveys.

The result of this collaboration is the creation of the Campus Sustainability Data Collector hosted by AASHE. The Data Collector is modeled after the STARS Reporting Tool and is available at no cost. However, this option does not include all of the benefits of the STARS Reporting Tool or those associated with being a STARS Participant.

How do STARS and the American College and University Presidents’ Climate Commitment (ACUPCC) complement each other?
STARS® is a transparent, self-reporting framework for colleges and universities to measure their comprehensive sustainability performance in all areas of the campus including Education & Research, Operations, and Planning, Administration & Engagement.  Data from STARS Participants’ STARS Reports are available publicly allowing all Participants to share their sustainability practices and programs with the higher education community as well as benchmark their successes over time.  The ACUPCC is a pledge made by college and university presidents on behalf of their institutions, to pursue climate neutrality in campus operations, to promote the education, research and community engagement needed for the rest of society to do the same, and to hold themselves accountable by publicly reporting on their progress.   

Activities that are required under the ACUPCC are rewarded with points in several STARS credits.  For example, creating a climate action plan, conducting an inventory of greenhouse gas emissions, developing a climate neutrality plan, incorporating sustainability in the curriculum, and greenhouse gas reduction measures (such as providing public transportation options, and minimizing waste) are all actions that contribute to fulfilling the ACUPCC and will also earn an institution points in STARS. 

AASHE, along with Second Nature and eco-America, was an original supporting organization of the ACUPCC and continues to be  a supporting organization. AASHE is also the organization that hosts and maintains STARS. Second Nature is the lead supporting organization of the ACUPCC and a Founding Partner of the STARS Program.

fields.content:

Do you have to be an AASHE member to sponsor STARS?
Any business may sponsor STARS regardless of whether or not it is an AASHE member. AASHE Associate Members receive a 5% discount on any STARS sponsorship, AASHE Business Supporter Members receive a 10% discount on any STARS sponsorship, and AASHE Business Leaders receive a 15% discount on any STARS sponsorship. Learn more about AASHE membership.

What are the STARS sponsorship levels and benefits?
There are three different levels of STARS sponsorship. All of these levels and the associated benefits are listed on the STARS Sponsorship web page.

What is the difference between sponsoring STARS and being a STARS Partner Organization?
Businesses have the opportunity to sponsor STARS while non-profit organizations can support STARS by signing on as a Partner Organization. Learn more about the STARS Governance Structure.

Who should I contact to become a STARS Sponsor or receive more information about sponsorship?
Anyone interested in STARS sponsorship or learning more about this opportunity is encouraged to email Meghan Fay Zahniser, STARS Program Manager at meghan@aashe.org.
