fields.title: Timeline
fields.content:
#mce_temp_url#[REPLACE WITH TIMELINE VISUAL]

The following table highlights milestones of the STARS program.

Jul. 2013

The 300th STARS report was submitted by Colgate University. STARS 2.0 was approved by the STARS Steering Committee.
Oct. 2012 AASHE launches the STARS 2.0 Public Comment Period. Universidad de Monterrey became the first institution outside the U.S. and Canada to receive a STARS rating.
May 2012 AASHE launches a new and improved brand.
Feb. 2012 AASHE releases STARS 1.2.  View a detailed Record of Changes (PDF). AASHE launches the Campus Sustainability Data Collector.
Oct. 2011 AASHE launches the STARS International Pilot.
Sept. 2011 AASHE releases Administrative Update One to STARS 1.1. View a detailed Record of Changes (pdf).
Feb. 2011 AASHE releases STARS 1.1.  View a detailed Record of Changes (pdf).
Jan. 31, 2011 STARS Charter Participant deadline. Submission deadline for institutions that registered for STARS between September 20, 2009 and January 31, 2010. Some institutions took a 6-month extension.
Nov. 2010 AASHE releases Administrative Update Two to STARS 1.0.  View a detailed Record of Changes (pdf).
Aug. 20, 2010 Deadline to register as a STARS Charter Participant.
June 2010 AASHE releases Administrative Update One to STARS 1.0.  View a detailed Record of Changes (pdf).
Jan. 19, 2010 AASHE launches STARS 1.0 with the webinar "Measuring Campus Sustainability:  Reaching for the STARS", which kicks off the STARS webinar series.
Sept. - Dec. 2009 Minor administrative updates made to the STARS Technical Manual. View a detailed Record of Changes (pdf).
Sept. 20, 2009 STARS 1.0 Early Release launches at Greening of the Campus VIII: Embracing Change and STARS Charter Participant registration begins.
Feb - Aug. 2009 AASHE compiles the results from the STARS pilot project and collects additional feedback from advisors to inform the credit revision process.
Jan. 2009 STARS pilot period ends. View STARS Pilot Results (pdf).
Sept. 2008 Phase Two of the STARS Pilot Project begins.  View Guide to STARS Pilot Phase Two (pdf).
April 2008 AASHE releases STARS 0.5 (pdf), which opens a public comment period that lasts until May 30, 2008. View feedback received (pdf).
Feb. 2008 Phase One of the STARS Pilot Project begins. View Guide to STARS Pilot Phase One (pdf) and information about the pilot project.
Oct. - Dec. 2007 AASHE conducts focused conference calls with experts and interested parties. View call schedule and notes.
Sept. - Dec. 2007 Experts from throughout the sustainability and higher education communities provide feedback on the draft system. View feedback provided (pdf) and survey results (pdf).
Sept. 2007 AASHE releases STARS 0.4, a draft version of the rating system that includes potential credits. View STARS 0.4 (pdf).
Oct. 2006 - Sept. 2007 AASHE gathers feedback from workshop participants at several campus sustainability conferences, including AASHE 2006, the 2007 Rocky Mountain Sustainability Summit (pdf), the 2007 Smart and Sustainable Campuses Conference (pdf), and the 2007 Greening of the Campus Conference.
Aug. 2006 Higher Education Associations Sustainability Consortium (HEASC) issues a call for AASHE to develop a campus sustainability rating system. View the call.

fields.title: Step-by-Step Through the STARS Process
fields.content:
Interested in participating in STARS but unsure of what is involved?  This step-by-step guide outlines the details of the STARS process from registration to submission.  Find additional details about the STARS process in the "Help" section of the STARS website.

1) Determine if STARS is Right for your Institution:

  • Review the STARS Credit Checklist (pdf) (Excel) for an overview of the credits included in STARS
  • Download a free copy of the STARS Technical Manual for full details about STARS
  • Check out the benefits of participating
  • Review the STARS FAQs or contact stars@aashe.org if you have any questions

2) Register:

  • If you don’t have one already, create an AASHE Account. Anyone may create an AASHE Account, and users must log in with their AASHE Account in order to register for STARS.
  • Provide the name and contact information for the institution’s STARS Liaison (the primary point of contact at the institution on STARS issues).
  • Provide the name and contact information for one executive-level administrator (president, chancellor, vice president, vice chancellor, or provost) for AASHE to copy on the registration confirmation e-mail. Copying an administrator on the registration e-mail helps ensure that each institution’s leadership is aware of its participation in STARS.
  • Agree to the STARS Terms and Conditions of Use.
  • Make a one-time payment that covers registration, access to the Reporting Tool for one year, and one submission. Registrants may pay by credit card or check.
  • Use the STARS Participant logo and template press release to publicize your institution’s participation in the program.

3) Report and Share Information:

  • Use your AASHE Account to log-in to the STARS website and access the Reporting Tool.
  • Grant others access to enter data so they can help with the reporting process.
  • Specify the boundary for your institution’s STARS submission. The institutional boundary refers to the portions of the physical campus that are included. Each institution is expected to include its entire main campus when reporting. It may choose whether or not to include satellite campuses and other land holdings.
  • Enter data and information that meets the specifications for each credit. (The STARS Technical Manual includes a list of reporting fields for each credit.)
  • Affirm the accuracy of the information submitted by specifying a responsible party for each credit and providing his or her contact information.
  • STARS Participants also have the option of sharing their data with The Princeton Review, Sierra magazine, and/or the Sustainable Endowments Institute. These organizations are interested in institutions completing as much of STARS as possible, in addition to the supplemental section. The supplement section includes additional fields, outside of the STARS reporting fields that hold no weight on a STARS rating.

4) Submit for a Rating:

  • Double-check all of the saved information to make sure it’s accurate.
  • Upload a letter from the president or chancellor that affirms the accuracy of the submission.
  • Determine if you want to submit as a Reporter.
  • Submit all information. All data and credit information will be publicly posted on the STARS website upon submission.

5) Spread the Word:

  • Highlight your achievements by using the STARS rating logo and issuing a press release.
  • Renew your institutions participation with STARS.  Institutions that renew within 90 days of their access to the STARS Reporting Tool expiring are eligible for a 50% discount (i.e. $450 for AASHE members and $700 for non-members instead of $900 for AASHE members and $1,400 for non-members). 

6) Repeat the Process:

  •  A STARS rating is valid for three years, but an institution may choose to submit its data as often as once per 12-month subscription with STARS.  Remember that updates to your information are only made public when you submit your data.

fields.content:

Jan. 19, 2010 AASHE launches STARS 1.0 with the webinar "Measuring Campus Sustainability:  Reaching for the STARS", which kicks off the STARS webinar series.
Sept. - Dec. 2009 Minor administrative updates made to the STARS Technical Manual. View a detailed Record of Changes (pdf).
Sept. 20, 2009 STARS 1.0 Early Release launches at Greening of the Campus VIII: Embracing Change and STARS Charter Participant registration begins.
Feb - Aug. 2009 AASHE compiles the results from the STARS pilot project and collects additional feedback from advisors to inform the credit revision process.
Jan. 2009 STARS pilot period ends. View STARS Pilot Results (pdf).
Sept. 2008 Phase Two of the STARS Pilot Project begins.  View Guide to STARS Pilot Phase Two (pdf).
April 2008 AASHE releases STARS 0.5 (pdf), which opens a public comment period that lasts until May 30, 2008. View feedback received (pdf).
Feb. 2008 Phase One of the STARS Pilot Project begins. View Guide to STARS Pilot Phase One (pdf) and information about the pilot project.
Oct. - Dec. 2007 AASHE conducts focused conference calls with experts and interested parties. View call schedule and notes.
Sept. - Dec. 2007 Experts from throughout the sustainability and higher education communities provide feedback on the draft system. View feedback provided (pdf) and survey results (pdf).
Sept. 2007 AASHE releases STARS 0.4, a draft version of the rating system that includes potential credits. View STARS 0.4 (pdf).
Oct. 2006 - Sept. 2007 AASHE gathers feedback from workshop participants at several campus sustainability conferences, including AASHE 2006, the 2007 Rocky Mountain Sustainability Summit (pdf), the 2007 Smart and Sustainable Campuses Conference (pdf), and the 2007 Greening of the Campus Conference.
Aug. 2006 Higher Education Associations Sustainability Consortium (HEASC) issues a call for AASHE to develop a campus sustainability rating system. View the call.

How was STARS developed?
Why does STARS include “social” indicators? Isn’t sustainability mostly about the environment?
What are the main differences between the credits in the STARS Pilot and STARS 1.0?
How will the system be updated?
When will the system be updated?

How was STARS developed?
In 2006 the Higher Education Associations' Sustainability Consortium (HEASC), an informal network of higher education associations with a commitment to sustainability, issued a call for a campus sustainability rating system (pdf). Since then, AASHE has worked collaboratively with other non-profits and higher education associations on the development of STARS. A Steering Committee, Strategic Advisory Committee, and a Technical Advisory Committee weighed in on the system and nearly 70 institutions participated in a year-long pilot program.

Why does STARS include “social” indicators? Isn’t sustainability mostly about the environment?
The most commonly used definition of sustainability–meeting the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs–is from Our Common Future: The Report of the World Commission on Environment and Development, commonly known as the Brundtland Commission report. The interconnectedness and interdependence of the social, environmental, and economic dimensions of sustainability are included throughout Our Common Future. The Brundtland Commission writes, “our inability to promote the common interest in sustainable development is often a product of the relative neglect of economic and social justice.” The report continues, “[a] world in which poverty and inequity are endemic will always be prone to ecological and other crises. Sustainable development requires meeting the basic needs of all and extending to all the opportunity to satisfy their aspirations for a better life.” And, "[e]ven the narrow notion of physical sustainability implies a concern for social equity between generations, a concern that must logically be extended to equity within each generation."

Many popular uses of and references to sustainability also emphasize the concept’s economic, environmental, and social dimensions. For example, businesses talk about the triple bottom line: people, planet, and profits (or, alternately, human capital, natural capital, and financial capital). Likewise, sustainability educators commonly refer to the Three Es of sustainability: economy, ecology, and equity. Similarly, popular representations of sustainability underscore the concept’s three dimensions. Sustainability experts often use a three-legged stool as a symbol for sustainability. The social, economic, and environmental components of sustainability each represent one of the stool’s legs. If one of the legs is missing, the stool cannot balance or function. Another common illustration of sustainability is a diagram depicting three overlapping circles, representing environmental needs, economic needs and social needs. The area where the circles overlap and all three needs are met is the area of sustainability.

STARS represents an attempt to translate this broad and inclusive view of sustainability to measurable objectives at the campus level. Thus, it includes credits related to an institution’s environmental, social, and economic performance.

What are the main differences between the STARS Pilot and STARS 1.0?
First, some credits–particularly those for which gathering data proved especially difficult or impossible–have been eliminated. In addition, STARS 1.0 does not include prerequisites.

Second, additional definitions and guidelines have been added to many credits in an effort to make the credit criteria clearer.

Third, for the first time, AASHE has gone through a deliberate credit weighting or point allocation exercise. In other words, the point value assigned to each credit has been evaluated relative to other credits such that the credits that have the greatest impact on an institutions’ sustainability performance are worth the most points.

Fourth, many credits have been restructured such that partial points are available. This approach better recognizes incremental change and creates a stronger incentive for continued progress toward sustainability.

How will the system be updated?
AASHE will continue to work with STARS participants and the campus sustainability community to improve the system. Comments or feedback on STARS may be sent to the STARS staff at any time (stars@aashe.org). Before a new version (e.g., STARS 2.0) is released, AASHE will hold a public comment period to allow stakeholders an opportunity to comment on proposed changes. View details about the development process and timeline in the Technical Development Policy (pdf).

When will the system be updated?
Major changes to the system will likely occur every two or three years. In the mean time, AASHE may make small changes and clarifying edits to the STARS Technical Manual to respond to participants’ needs.  View details about the development process and timeline (pdf).

fields.title: STARS Pilot Project
fields.content:
STARS Pilot Project
Institutions Participating in the STARS Pilot
STARS Pilot Project Conference Calls

Approach

The STARS pilot project took place from February 2008 to January 2009. Institutions that participated in the pilot tested the system and provided feedback to AASHE to help shape future versions of STARS. 

The STARS pilot project took place in two phases. A phased approach helped to moderate the workload for participating institutions. It also allowed AASHE to solicit another round of feedback about some sections included in STARS before asking schools to gather data.

Phase One of the STARS pilot started in February 2008. Phase One covers the Operations category and about half of the Administration and Finance category. View STARS Guide to Pilot Phase One (pdf). 

STARS Pilot Phase Two started in September 2008.  Phase Two covers the Education and Research category and remaining credits in the Administration and Finance category, as well as Tier Two Credits and Innovation Credits.  View STARS Guide to Pilot Phase Two (pdf).

Results

The Sustainability Tracking, Assessment & Rating System Pilot Project Results (pdf) is a detailed summary of results and feedback received during the pilot project.

Student Research

Kyle Murphy, a student at The Evergreen State College, coordinated his institution's participation in the STARS Pilot Project and wrote his Master's thesis about lessons learned from that experience.  He writes:

This research focused on three main questions with respect to Evergreen’s use of the STARS tool: (a) Is STARS an effective tool for use at Evergreen (did the framework address issues important to Evergreen, did it meet the criteria of an ideal assessment framework, and what are the advantages and disadvantages), (b) Does the STARS process lead to organizational learning, and (c) What STARS reveal about Evergreen’s commitment to sustainability. Using a case study research design, I took a multi-disciplinary approach to the data collection for STARS implementation. Through my research I found that STARS is an effective tool to evaluate sustainability at Evergreen, which led to organizational learning, and highlighted Evergreen’s complex and dynamic commitment to sustainability.

Thesis presentation (pdf)
Thesis full text (pdf)

fields.title: Students and STARS
fields.content:
Are you a student that is interested in participating in STARS on your campus?  Are you looking for information to encourage your institution to register for STARS?  AASHE and STARS can support your involvement in the campus sustainability movement.  This web page outlines several resources to get you started with STARS or enhance your current involvement in the program. 

Quick links to topics on this page:

What is STARS?
Why is STARS important to students?
How can I get my institution involved in STARS?
How can I connect with campus stakeholders to share information about STARS?
If my institution is a STARS Participant how can I be involved?
What helpful resources will help me stay engaged with AASHE and STARS?
Who do I contact regarding questions about the STARS Program?

What is STARS?

View this informative video about the STARS Program that was created by students at the State University of New York at New Paltz.

Why is STARS important to students?

The Sustainability Tracking, Assessment & Rating System™ (STARS) is a transparent, self-reporting framework for colleges and universities to measure their sustainability performance. Although it is important for campus administrators, faculty, and staff to be involved in the cross-campus collaboration necessary to complete an institution’s STARS Report, students have a great opportunity to be involved too.

As a student participating in STARS through coursework, an independent project, an internship, as a volunteer, or even a paid employee, your involvement will provide you with valuable skills.  Some of these skills may include: learning comprehensive data collection techniques, organizing disparate types of data and ways to conduct yourself in an interview or when working with campus stakeholders – all of which are valuable lessons that will be beneficial throughout your academic and professional careers.

Even if your institution is a registered STARS Participant, or not, this page will share information on the many ways for you to get involved.   Learn more about the details of the STARS Program.

 

How can I get my institution involved in STARS?

As a student, there are several was you can encourage your institution to participate in the STARS Program.  The first step is to determine if your institution is an AASHE Member.  Then, contact campus stakeholders to discuss your institution’s involvement in the STARS Program. 

Ways to familiarize yourself with STARS:

  • Gather information on registering for the STARS Program.
  • Review the STARS Technical Manual.
  • Learn helpful details about STARS Reporting, Rating, and Scoring.
  • Share the STARS Governance Structure with campus stakeholders.
  • View a helpful webinar on "Achieving Administrative Support for STARS."

 

How can I connect with campus stakeholders to share information about STARS?

Utilize these helpful email templates* when contacting campus stakeholders:

  • Introducing STARS to Your Campus Administrators (doc)
  • Encouraging Faculty to Use STARS in Courses (doc)

*For institution's that are registered STARS Participants, additional email templates are available in the "My Resources" section of the STARS Reporting Tool.  Please note, you must be listed as a "user" on your institution's STARS Report to access this information.  Contact stars@aashe.org for more information.

 

If my institution is a STARS Participant how can I be involved?

The STARS Liaison is the main contact regarding your institution’s participation in the STARS Program.  Reaching out to this individual is a great way to become involved with STARS on your campus. 

  • Contact stars@aashe.org if you are unaware of your institution’s STARS Liaison.  The STARS staff will be able to help you connect with this individual.
  • Contact your institution’s STARS Liaison, share your interest, and discuss your role.
  • Learn how students are engaged on other campuses.
  • Become familiar with data collection strategies.

 

What helpful resources will help me stay engaged with AASHE and STARS?

  • Create an AASHE account (Note: you do not have to be affiliated with an AASHE Member institution to create an AASHE account).
  • Find valuable sustainability resources in the AASHE Campus Sustainability Resource Center.
  • Subscribe to AASHE Newsletters.
  • Participate in AASHE and STARS events.
  • Post on the AASHE Campus Sustainability Discussion Forums.
  • Contribute to the AASHE Blog: Campus Sustainability Perspectives.
  • Share the STARS Overview Presentation. (pdf)

 

Who do I contact regarding questions about the STARS Program?

Submit your inquiries to stars@aashe.org to connect with an AASHE Staff person about the STARS Program.

See the “Get Involved” section of the AASHE website to learn more ways to stay engaged with the campus sustainability community.

fields.title: Sponsorship Opportunities
fields.content:
The Sustainability Tracking, Assessment & Rating System (STARS), a program of AASHE, is rapidly gaining recognition as the preferred tool for measuring campus sustainability. The number of STARS Participants, the number of visits to the STARS website, and STARS educational opportunities are increasingly growing.

STARS sponsorship provides an outstanding opportunity for companies to demonstrate their support of campus sustainability and to increase their visibility among campus decision-makers who are seriously engaged in sustainability. Any company or organization interested in sponsoring STARS should contact Meghan Fay Zahniser, STARS Program Manager, at meghan@aashe.org.

Three Star Annual Sponsorship: $15,000*

For those companies that want to show the highest level of commitment to supporting AASHE's STARS Program and receive extensive opportunities for exposure to the campus sustainability community, we offer the following benefits:

  • Logo, link, and brief text description (up to 100 words related to company's support of campus sustainability) included in the STARS annual report
  • Logo included on sponsor slide in all AASHE presentations on STARS including webinars.
  • Logo, link, and text description (up to 100 words related to company's support of campus sustainability) included on Sponsors page of STARS website for one year.
  • Opportunity to give a 1 minute introduction during a STARS webinar and include company logo on the first webinar slide.
  • Logo recognition on the STARS homepage for one year.

Two Star Annual Sponsorship: $10,000*

For those companies who understand the importance of STARS in shaping campus sustainability and want to demonstrate their support as well as receive significant exposure to the campus sustainability community, we offer the following opportunities:

  • Logo, link, and brief text description (up to 50 words related to company's support of campus sustainability) included in the STARS annual report.
  • Logo included on sponsor slide in all AASHE presentations on STARS including webinars.
  • Logo, link, and brief text description (up to 50 words related to company's support of campus sustainability) included on Sponsors page of STARS website for one year.

One Star Annual Sponsorship: $5,000*

For those companies who recognize STARS as an important way to connect to the campus sustainability community, we offer the following advertising opportunities:

  • Logo and link included in the STARS annual report.
  • Logo, link, and brief text description (up to 25 words related to company's support of campus sustainability) included on Sponsors page of the STARS website for one year.

*In becoming a STARS Sponsor, your company can benefit from becoming an AASHE Associate Member. AASHE Business Affiliates (the basic level of business membership) receive a 5% discount on any STARS sponsorship level; Business Supporters receive a 10% discount; and Business Leaders (the highest level of membership) receive a 15% discount on any STARS sponsorship. Learn more about AASHE's Business Alliance Program.

fields.title: STARS International Pilot
fields.content:
Due to growing interest at the international level, the Association for the Advancement of Sustainability in Higher Education (AASHE) implemented a pilot program to welcome higher education institutions worldwide to participate in the Sustainability Tracking, Assessment & Rating System™ (STARS) Program. STARS® was launched by AASHE in January 2010 after several years of research and development by the higher education and sustainability communities in the U.S. and Canada. The STARS International Pilot (pdf) was an opportunity for colleges and universities located outside the U.S. and Canada to participate in STARS and publicly document their efforts related to sustainability. The pilot provided an opportunity for international institutions to share feedback and make suggestions for improvements to the system. The results of the pilot will be used to help determine the eventual role of STARS in a global context.

Please note, registration for the STARS International Pilot closed on Dec. 31, 2012.  Questions about the program may be emailed to stars@aashe.org.

Benefits of Participating

STARS will help institutions set and meet sustainability goals and will foster information sharing about practices and performance among the campus sustainability community. All schools that register for STARS will receive positive recognition as STARS Participants and gain recognition for their sustainability efforts. To further the evolution of STARS, institutions that register for the pilot will be responsible for providing feedback on their experience.

The cost of participating in STARS is $900 for AASHE members and $1400 for non-members. However, eligible institutions were invited to participate in the STARS International Pilot for free. This means that upon registration, such institutions gained access to the online STARS Reporting Tool at no cost and, after going through the data collection process, had their STARS Report published on the STARS website.

Key Points to Consider 

The initial intent of STARS was for the system to be used by U.S. and Canadian institutions, therefore there may be some challenges associated with implementing the current version of STARS internationally. Colleges and universities that participated in the STARS International Pilot were eligible to receive the recognition of STARS Reporter, but not the bronze, silver, gold, and platinum rating levels. The benefit of being a STARS Reporter is that institutions are able to select the credits they’d like to pursue without having to complete the entire assessment. In addition, STARS Reporters are recognized for publicly reporting their sustainability data, but no scores are made available to the public.

To be eligible to participate in the STARS International Pilot, an institution must have been a higher education college or university based in a country outside of the U.S. or Canada. Participation in the pilot was limited to 50 institutions. Registration closed Dec. 31, 2012. AASHE recommends interested institutions read through the STARS International Pilot guidelines (pdf) carefully.

Prior to registration, AASHE encouraged interested institutions to review the STARS Credit Checklist and STARS Technical Manual. These documents provide a detailed overview of the STARS process and may illuminate aspects of the system that may be challenging to implement.

View the details regarding the guidelines (pdf) for the STARS International Pilot. Contact stars@aashe.org with any questions.
